text:
¬†@rhenriques11¬† The 97% consensus is made up of publishing climate scientists active in the field. Happer is not one of these.  He does not work with climate, has written no climate change papers and has no formal training in it. He has even been refuted by his own American Physical Society, who vehemently disagree with him. 

The 97% consensus, in fact, is confirmed by eight separate peer-reveiwed studies. EIGHT. (Oreskes, 2004; Doran, 2009; Anderegg, 2010; Cook, 2013; Verheggan, 2014; Stenhouse, 2014; Carlton, 2015; Powell, 2019.)


Naomi Oreskes has been a professor of science history at the University of California and professor of Earth and Planetary Sciences at Harvard University.  She has worked on studies of geophysics, environmental issues and global warming, as well as the history of science. 

Michael Mann is a climatologist and geophysicist and director of the Earth System Science Center at Pennsylvania State University. He has authored over 200 peer-reviewed scientific papers and is best known for his hockey stick data, which has been confirmed by two dozen follow-up studies by other scientists and affirmed by the National Academy of Sciences. 

The 97% consensus is publicly endorsed by the IPCC and 170 major scientific institutions and academies of science around the world. Not a single scientific institution with national or international standing rejects it. 

Here are the endorsing scientific institutions. I urge you to visit their websites and read their public positions on climate change. Hopefully it will begin to illuminate to you just how far afield from the empirical evidence William Happer is. (See CLIMATE MISINFORMATION BY SOURCE: WILLIAM HAPPER for details on why he is wrong.)

No scientist can simply make things up to satisfy anyone's "agenda." Any data gathered must be PROVEN with quantitative evidence. The evidence then must be peer reviewed, published, debated with other scientists and then replicated and corroborated by others. You can't cheat without being caught. And if you're caught, you lose your funding, your reputation and your career.

text:
¬†@Kevin Jenkins¬† I watched the video. It's wrong on nearly every count. Happer says doubling CO2 will do little or nothing to raise temperature. ALL of the scientific data and the official IPCC position is that a doubling of CO2 will, in the short term, raise global temperature 3C and, over the long term, 6C, more than enough to cause catastrophe. 

You can listen to Happer, who is not a climate scientist and has no data to back his viewpoint, and who was funded for years by the fossil fuel industry when he ran the CO2 Coalition to increase fossil fuel usage, or you can believe the scientific literature and the world's publishing climate scientists. 

CO2-driven warming is already raising average global temperature. 19 of the last 20 years were the warmest on record, according to all six of the world's leading climate data centers. 2020 was tied for first.

That warming is melting icecaps and glaciers at rates unprecedented in recorded history. The meltwater is raising sea levels 5mm per year, according to the World Meteorological Organization. That's up from 1.5mm per year throughout most of the 20th century. 

According to NOAA, high tide flooding has risen 140% along the American northeast in just the last 20 years. It's up an astonishing 190% along the southeast. It's why the City Dock neighborhood of Annapolis is flooding out 65 times a year and why Miami has elevated seawalls, moved buildings and raised 105 miles of roads. It's also why New York has a new $10 billion-dollar flood mitigation project the works. 

The data also shows that wildfire seasons around the world have expanded by a month; extreme precipitation events have risen sharply, and droughts are increasing in severity. While category 1 and 2 huricanes have declined, cat 4 and 5 hurricanes have nearly doubled over the last 35 years, according to the very latest research.

Happer is just plain wrong, and there are really sound reasons why the world's scientists refute him.

text:
No need to debate Gore. William Happer is refuted by 97% of the world's publishing climate scientists, the IPCC, and the 170 scientific institutions that publicly endorse the consensus findings. Happer is not a climate scientist,  has no formal training in climate change science and has written no studies on climate change. His speciality is OPTICS. 

The Little Ice Age did not occur worldwide, nor did the cooling happen at the same time. The cooling that did happen was produced by volcanic activity (Miller et al) and a grand solar minimum known as the Maunder Minimum, which dropped global temperatures by an additional half a degree.

The Industrial Revolution started in 1760. 

Average global temperature has risen 1 degree Celsius since the Industrial Revolution, but global warming actually concentrates at the poles, which is why average winter temperature in Faribanks and Anchorage, Alaska has risen an astonishing 8 degrees F since 1970. Barrow's winter temperature has risen 9 degrees. Greenland's average temperature has risen 7 degrees since 1991. 

Contrary to popular internet mythology, the majority of climate scientists were warning of increasing warming, not cooling, in the 1970s. See MYTH OF 1970S COOLING and check it out. Sensationalist articles in Time and Newsweek, however, made it appear as if we were headed for a long-term cooling, which was not supported by the data.

text:
Yes, they do it in sixth grade science classes. Take two bottles, fill them half full with water. Drop 4 Alka Seltzer tablets into one, suspend thermometers inside both bottles (not in the water), and seal. Take a heat lamp and warm both bottles. Come back in 30 minutes. The bottle air containing the CO2 from the tablets will be subtantially warmer than the other bottle. 

On a larger scale, spectroscopic analysis outside clearly shows heat passing through molecules of CO2 in the atmosphere and radiating back to earth. Isotopic analysis differentiates the natural CO2 in the atmosphere from the CO2 produced by the burning of fossil fuels. That's how we know that we've added 47% to the total accumulation since the Industrial Revolution.

author: Curt Sherrer

text:
I've only recently come across this Youtube channel, which seems to feature mostly very conservative content.  In general I disagree with most of it, but even a broken clock is right twice a day, and in this particular case the speaker, who is clearly an eminent scientist (who co-wrote a paper with Freeman Dyson, and is/was? on the physics faculty at Princeton), may be making some points that are, at some level, at least cogent.  Science cannot function properly without skepticism and climate science should be more welcoming of scientists willing to come forward with controversial or contrary perspectives.  

Though personally definitely liberal in most respects, the "theory" of global warming has always struck me as falling short of a scientific standard, certainly insofar as projecting the future of the earth's climate many years into the future are not within the range of things that science can reliably predict.  We can say with considerable precision where each of the planets will be relative to each other hundreds of years from now, and can exactly predict the inter-actions of subatomic particles in isolated systems,  we cannot predict complex, emergent phenomena like climate with any similar level of reliability, and arguably, making predictions about the climate 50-100 years from now is a little bit silly.

The professor clearly has a political axe to grind, making sarcastic comments about B. Sanders and OAC.  Bringing politics into science, in any way, is a generally bad idea.  So in that respect his comments seems to be subject to personal bias.  But I completely agree with his comments as regards the fact that many scientific ideas turn out to be wrong; in fact the vast majority of scientific theories are eventually superseded or proven outright false.  I say that not to cast aspersion on science, but merely to point out that this is how science progresses -- by posing theories that can be proven or dis-proven and retaining only those that stand up to experiment.

There is a somewhat persuasive argument that it is better to err on the side of caution when it comes to climate change, and I agree but have a different take on that.  I think climate change should be taken very seriously, but we should be preparing for climate change of various different kinds, such as the climate becoming colder as well as becoming warmer.  

I do not think we yet have the scientific prowess (specifically the computing prowess) to predict climate in the long term future.  But we do know from the geologic record that climate does change, and sometimes changes radically, in relatively short periods of time.  Many of the changes that have occurred with comparative regularity in the geologic record would be very challenging to human civilization.  So it would be a good idea to study the diversity of climatic conditions known to be possible in our terrestrial environment, and to prepare as may be practical for those that are adverse, particularly if likely to cause catastrophic harm.

text:
¬†@herrschaftg35¬† Sorry, no. The 97% consensus has been confirmed by seven separate studies. SEVEN. You're ciitng the Cook study and ignoring all others. And you're leaving out some vital details of that Cook study.

About two-thirds of the Cook papers surveyed didn't express a position on the subject in the abstracts because 1) most journals have strict word limits for their abstracts, and 2)  every scientist doing climate research knows humans are causing global warming. There's no longer a need to state something so obvious. For example, would you expect every geological paper to note in its abstract that the Earth is a spherical body that orbits the sun?

In scientific papers, scientists generally focus their discussions on questions that are still disputed or unanswered rather than on matters about which everyone agrees. 

Thus papers in which a position isn't overtly stated hardly means the author rejects anthropogenic climate change. 

This argument over the Cook study is seen again and again in denier sites, with all the other studies rarely if ever mentioned. Taken as a whole, when ALL the data is assessed from ALL of the studies, the 97% consensus holds true.
author: SwiftlyTiltingPlanet

text:
¬†@SwiftlyTiltingPlanet¬†: You claim that two thirds of the papers had nothing to do with climate change yet I call bullshit. The fact remains that only a third of the papers reviewed had any indication that man had any effect on natural climate change. All others were dismissed because they didn‚Äôt meet that specific agenda. Hence why we get this completely false percentage of 97%. 

Not surprising that the majority of ‚Äúscientists‚Äù receiving funding through grants magically claim man-made climate change is real. Especially since the science behind man-made climate change is backed only by speculation, not proof. Absolutely no bias there‚Ä¶

You seem to believe man-made climate change is real. So where are the experiments proving that a mere 100ppm of CO2, or even a small increase in methane are indeed warming the atmosphere? Where are the experiments proving that a few degrees a century are the cause of rising sea water? Where are the experiments proving that man-made climate change are effecting the electromagnetic fields on the planet ultimately effecting weather?

Two thirds of the papers, though, didn't overtly state their position on climate change one way or another because every scientist doing climate research knows humans are driving change and it would be stating the obvious, on a par with telling fellow geologists in a paper that "the earth is round." 

And it's interesting that you hyper-focus on Cook's study while ignoring what all the other studies said which, taken together and averaged, agreed on the 97%.

Funding is given to scientists to gather data, not prove climate change. Conclusions are reached after the data is analyzed, not before, and funders have no say in the outcomes nor their interpretations. 

No scientist can simply make things up to satisfy anyone's "agenda." Any data gathered must be PROVEN with quantitative evidence. The evidence then must be peer reviewed, published, debated with other scientists and then replicated and corroborated by others. You can't cheat without being caught. And if you're caught, you lose your funding, your reputation and your career.

text:
¬†@herrschaftg35¬† 1. Earth's temperature began to rise at the beginning of the Industrial Revolution.
2. The rise in temperature followed the rise in CO2, as it did throughout millions of years of earth history.
3. Spectroscopic analysis clearly shows heat flowing through molecules of C02 in the atmosphere and radiating back to earth, so we know for certain that a greenhouse effect exists.
4. We can differentiate fossil fuel CO2 molecules from natural CO2 molecules through isotopic analysis. This is how we know that a substantial and growing portion of atmospheric CO2 is coming directly from fossil fuels. We've added about 47% to the total accumulation since the Industrial Revolution. 
5. As our lower atmosphere has warmed, the atmospheric layer just above it has COOLED, according to NASA monitoring since 1978. That's evidence of heat being trapped below. Neither the sun nor any natural warming force on earth can simultaneously warm the lower atmosphere while cooling the atmopheric layer above it. Only a greenhouse effect can do that.
6. Global warming concentrates at the poles, which is why average winter temperature in Fairbanks and Anchorage, Alaska has risen an astonishing 8.1 degrees F since 1970. Greenland's average temperature has risen 7 degrees since 1991. 
7. The warming at the poles is why icecaps and glaciers there are melting at rates unprecedented in recorded history.
8. The meltig ice is raising sea levels. Over the last five years, according to the WMO, average sea level rise was 5mm per year. That's up from 1.5mm per year throughout most of the 20th century. According to NOAA, high tide flooding along the American northeast coast has risen 140% in just 20 years. It's up 190% along the southeast. It's why Miami has ras moved building and raised 105 miles of roads and why New York has a new $10 billion flood mitigation project in the works. 
9. There is no shortage of empirical evidence proving man's contribution to climate change, but you'll never see it presented at conservative media outlets like Hillsdale College. Go to SkepticalScience.com and take a deep dive into the data. They'll answer all your questions and address your suspicions with detailed explanations and citations and links to original studies.

text:
¬†@SwiftlyTiltingPlanet¬† I'm not endorsing his specific ideas, but rather diversity of opinion in this particular area of science.  It seems odd to me that scientists who hold a differing view about global warming are referred to (by Wikipedia and others) as "climate change deniers', as though they are denying the Holocaust, while at the same time there are university scientists who believe Einstein's theories of Relativity are incorrect and their work is encouraged.

Also, I agree with his comments, made elsewhere, that climate change/ global warming advocates often have something in common with Harri Krishna devotees, insofar as it has become a religious belief for many of those who most passionately support it.  I am not really aware of any scientists who are passionate advocates the ideas in a like sense.  I call the global warming view 'ideas' because I don't know how they can be made out as a scientific theory in a formal sense.   Yes, I'm aware that an overwhelmingly large number scientists agree about human contribution to emission of greenhouse  and warming climate and acknowledge that the validity of scientific ideas is generally judged by consensus agreement.  Obviously it is the case that humans contribute to emission of greenhouse gasses, and that these gasses are a factor in climate warming.   

But I just don't think the implications are as  clear as some would have it, nor do I think the political momentum behind spending on that specific future threat is wholly justified, as there are far more grave threats to humanity than climate change, which is something we can probably adapt to, whereas thermo-nuclear war, for example, is not.
author: K Schuman

text:
¬†@K Schuman¬† Nobody in science is stopping contrarians from publishing scientific papers opposing the consensus findings. Their work continues to be published. However, their work continues to be debunked as well. 

Unknown to most of the public, a large portion of those who appear in media with contrarian views are funded by the fossil fuel industry. Representing the interests of the industry is perfectly acceptable. However, it's unacceptable to misrepresent the science, which is what they often do. 

According to investigations by Drexel University and the Union of Concerned Scientists, the fossil fuel industry has funded nearly 100 climate change denial organizations, front groups and websites. Their presentations often look like legitimate science. But they're not. They typically employ cherry-picked data, verbal sleight of hand and little lies of omission to sow seeds of doubt in the public's mind. 

I've been a science writer since the 1970s. I've worked with scientists from around the world and have been published in multiple languages. I work with climate data every day, and the most critical thing I can share with you is that scoffing, skepticism and suspicion often go hand in hand with misinformation or missing information. Most people simply don't know what they don't know. There is nothing inherently wrong with that. We all have holes in our knowledge.

The more you learn about climate science, the more you'll come to realize that it has nothing to do with religiuos fervor or faith but everything to do with empirical evidence that has been verified and corroborated. There are now over a quarter of a million scientific papers on climate change in print. Most of the public will have read a fraction of 1% of these, if any.

If it's any consolation, I'm with you 100% on nuclear war. It is by far the greatest threat we face.
It only takes one crazy dictator with access to nuclear missiles to initiate World War III.

text: Sorry, but his comparisons are specious and his views are disputed by the preponderance of even more credentialed and respected scientists. Sure, CO2 is not a pollutant. In fact, the Earths atmosphere was almost entirely CO2 billions of years ago. Note that there were no humans or any other species we know today alive back then. No legitimate climate scientist argues that "pollution" is causing climate change. This is a GIANT red herring and a completely disingenuous argument. While CO2 may not be a pollutant, just try living in a sealed room filled with it. The big problem with CO2 is that it causes the Earth's atmosphere to retain HEAT. Heat that would normally escape into space. It's kind of like shutting up the house and turning the thermostat to the max (you'll probably survive, but it's a very, very bad environment). Well, it's even worse for the Earth. As the atmosphere heats, ice melts. And that vast, VAST melting pool of ice enters the oceans and raises sea levels. And that's not all, but it's bad enough. The greatest majority of the Earth's population lives on sea coasts or on rivers or lakes affected by sea level rise. If the sea level rose 10 feet over 10,000 years (which it has in the past, more than once), we could just gradually rebuild our cities further inland or on higher ground. But respected scientists who study this (not this guy) say the rate at which the atmosphere is heating means that we will all have to deal with flooding and terrible crazy weather patterns (scorching heat, massive tornadoes, hurricanes, wildfire-inducing droughts, crop failures and the like) not in 1000 or even 100 years, but within our own lifetimes or that of our children. This can wreak havoc on national economies, cause starvation due to crop failure and force millions to migrate. Please, before you believe what this crackpot claims, watch other videos. Watch lots of videos. Because if you tend to be skeptical, this guy claims are worthy of your disbelief.

text: Weather is what's happening in the atmosphere, on any given day, in a specific place. Local or regional weather forecasts include temperature, humidity, winds, cloudiness, and prospects for storms or other changes over the next few days. Climate is the average of these weather ingredients over many years. For example, it might be raining in Phoenix today, but they have a dry, hot climate because on average, it only rains a few days of the year. Weather can change day to day but climate changes slowly, over decades or centuries.
author: Eric Sandsogranite

text: Climate and weather are two different things. Nobody can predict the weather more than 3 days out because it can change by the hour. Not so climate. Climate is measured over 30-year spans over large swaths of land area and is very much predictable 10, 20 and even 30 years down the road.

text:
¬†@Blitzegron¬† Discovery Magazine didn't exist in the 70s. You're thinking of Newsweek. Both Time and Newsweek featured sensationalist stories about possible cooling but the outlier scientists they quoted DID NOT REPRESENT THE MAINSTREAM CONSENSUS. 

The global cooling scare of the 70s arose from a handful of scientists (not the majority, who were in fact warning about global warming even then) who worried about our ever-growing sulfate aerosol pollution problem. Sulfate aerosols, produced from burning coal, reflect sunlight and cool the planet the same way aerosols from volcanoes do. We were, in fact, in the middle of a slight cooling trend then, so the concern had some merit. 

Because aerosols were also causing premature deaths and massive health and lung problems worldwide, the U.S. decided to do something and passed the Clean Air Act (1970), which significantly reduced sulfate aerosol pollution. 

The long-lasting result was over $22 trillion in savings in health care, according to the EPA. Unfortunately, the drop in aerosols left C02 as the dominant pollutant, allowing it to continue to trap heat and raise global temperatures, just as MOST scientists in the 70s warned that it would. https://journals.ametsoc.org/view/journals/bams/89/9/2008bams2370_1.xml

No consensus of scientists predicted doomsday for 2000 or 2012. Movies? Yes. Scientists? No.

Data from the National Oceanography Centre at the University of Southhampton shows that historical C02 levels of around 400ppm typically result in sea level rises of 9 meters. It takes centuries to achieve that kind of rise, but it gives a good indication of where we're headed. The warning from history is that sea level can sometimes make big jumps in a short amount of time. During the Bolling Oscillation 14,600 years ago, sea level was rising 40mm per year.

text:
¬†@smevets804¬† Why would politicians "want to undermine our economy?" For what purpose?
Wouldn't hurting our economy destroy their chances of being re-elected? 

Multiple studies show that carbon taxing is the most efficient way to cut greenhouse gas emissions. Some countries offset the extra taxes by allowing tax refunds or credits for
homeowners who use green energy or energy efficient products.

The U.S. pays the second-lowest gasoline tax in the world. It's about one quarter of what most of the world pays. The low tax is why Americans have a love affair with SUVs and drive the largest cars in the world. The tax hasn't been raised for nearly 30 years. Are SUVs necessary?
Is it reasonable to feel entitled to everything we want or is it good to consider the health of the entire planet?

The UK‚Äôs¬†CO2¬†emissions fell by 2.9% in 2019, according to Carbon Brief analysis. That brought the total reduction to 29% over the past decade since 2010, even as the economy grew by a fifth. The UK proves that emissions can be lowered without hurting economies.

text:
¬†@jerryw66¬† There are great advantages to warming if you live away from the shoreline in far northern or southern latitudes. The big winner among global warming champions is Russia. The melting Arctic is opening up new profitable shipping lanes for them and the loss of permafrost is opening up new farmlands, just for starters. 

Because I work with climate data every day I can tell you that the IPCC is more than aware of the positives of climate change. Those calculations have been made. But at the end of the day, on balance, it will cost the world more than it will gain, according to all the data I've seen.

Interesting that because you apparently have no data to refute what I posted about Happer, you resort to projecting negative characterizations of me, and you don't even know me. I'm not the least bit "alarmed" by climate change. I live in a part of the world where we're more likely to win than lose. As a gardener, I'm happy about the earlier springs and shorter winters. 

I don't need a "book of common sense" since I've been around for a really long time. Climate change warrants concern, not panic or alarm. It's the same situation we faced in the 60s and 70s with massive sulfate aerosol pollution, which was killing millions prematurely from a variety of heart and lung issues.  Industry fought tooth and nail against passage of the Clean Air Act, just as they're fighting now. 


But today the United States has among the cleanest air in the world, among industrialized nations. Just compare us to China. That didn't happen by accident. It happened by listening to the science and acting on it, not ignoring it because it didn't affect us personally.

author: jerryw66

text:
¬†@jerryw66¬† Since I work with climate data every day, and have worked as a science writer since the 1970s, I'm more than familiar with earth's past climates. Major warm periods of the past were always caused by one of two forces: (1) massive tectonic upheaval, from the break-up of continents, which spewed trillions of tons of C02 into the atmosphere or (2) Milankovitch Cycles, changes in our orbit, axial tilt and precession that alter how much direct sunlight the earth recieves.

Past climate changes have NOTHING to do with our current warming. No natural forces are at work to warm the planet now. None. Nada. Zip. No Milankovitch Cycles (they're in cooling phases), no increased solar output (output has dropped since 1980), no massive tectonic upheaval to spew trillions of tons of C02 into the atmosphere. NOTHING. What we do have is a growing mass of anthropogenic C02 trapping heat in the atmosphere and radiating it back to earth.

UNSUBSIDIZED solar and wind are now the two cheapest forms of energy on earth. When you hear about expensive electric bills due to solar or wind it's always because of locked-in utility contracts signed 10 or 20 years ago, when the price of solar and wind were high. Germany, for example, won't get out of their locked-in contracts until the 2030s. But TODAY's prices of solar and wind are cheaper than oil, gas, coal and nuclear. 

You don't like solar and wind subsidies but are you okay with the fact that the world's fossil fuel industries received $5.2 trillion in subsidies in 2017, according to the International Monetary Fund?

The market system is already embracing renewable energy. The electric car market is poised to explode in the next five years, as EVs are now outperforming gasoline cars in nearly every category (emissions, cost to own, cost to drive per mile, etc). Kansas and Iowa now source over 40% of their power from wind. Oklahoma gets 37% of its power from wind. Many other states are sourcing over 20% from wind. South Australia and Denmark source 50%. Scotland produces enough wind energy to power all of its homes twice over. 

Beware of fossil fuel industry propaganda that works relentlessly to sow seeds of doubt about climate change and renewable energy. According to investigations by Drexel University and the Union of Concerned Scientists, they've funded nearly 100 climate change denial organiations, front groups and websites, and that includes William Happer's C02 Coalition, whose mission was to INCREASE the use of fossil fuels and cast doubt on the damaging effects of C02.

text:
¬†@Kent Keller¬† The Hillsdale College forum here does not allow links in posts. I've tried. They remove them with the entire post. They have deleted several of my posts because I had links in them. 

Let me know exactly what you'd like to know that isn't already glaringly obvious by the IPCC's refutation of Happer's beliefs. Happer, as we know, believes C02 is harmless. Neither the IPCC nor the 97% agree. That should be common knowledge.

Google the following:  "An Assessment of Earth's Climate Sensitivity Using Multiple Lines of Evidence"  This is the latest study by Sherwood et al that confirms the IPCC position that a doubling of C02 in the atmosphere would raise temperature by 3C. 

3C is more than enough to cause disaster. Yet Happer doesnt tell you that in his presentation. Instead he points to his graph (graphs deceive the unschooled more effectively than a thousand words) at the 25:00 mark and it appears as if a doubling of C02 would accomplish nothing. But that's NOT what the scientific data says. Read the study and then read the IPCC assessment of climate sensitivity.

The 3C rise in temperature is what happens in the short term. Over the long term, according to a study led by James Hansen, temperature rises by up to 6C. That's because as warming continues, melting icecaps reveal open land and water which, instead of reflecting sunlight as ice does, it absorbs it and produces more atmospheric heat. 

Happer doesn't like to talk about feedback effects like that. Feedback effects work synergistically with C02 to raise temperatures higher than C02 could do on its own. So he is stunningly disingenuous when he fails to mention them.

C02-driven warming accelerates evaporation, which fills the atmosphere with increased water vapor, itself a powerful greenhouse gas, which then works with C02 to increase temperatures even more. The release of methane from pent-up permafrost warms the planet further still. 

When you've read the climate sensitivity study, Google CLIMATE MISINFORMATION BY SOURCE: WILLIAM HAPPER  SkepticalScience has two different pages of Happer misnformation. One presents a short list of his erroneous beliefs, the other a more comprehensive overview. Click on each of his faulty statements there and delve into the actual data that shows how he is wrong. 

I'd be happy to answer anything else you want to know about Happer. As I'm sure you know, he took industry funding for years to head the C02 Coalition, whose sole mission was to increase the usage of fossil fuels. That in itself does not make him guilty. But coupled with all the science he gets wrong, whether willfully or unknowingly,  some serious fact-checking is warranted.
author: SwiftlyTiltingPlanet

text:
¬†@Kent Keller¬† Happer doesn't talk much about how hot it was in the ancient past, when C02 levels reached 1000ppm or higher. 252 million years ago, the Siberian Traps spewed so much C02 into the atmosphere that equatorial temperatures soared to 140 degrees, causing a mass extinction event known as "The Great Dying." (Google it). Over 90% of all marine animals and 2 out of 3 land animals died out from the heat.

And Happer's explanation of that heat? He has none. And that's because C02 was to blame. It's one of many inconvenient truths in the scientific literature that he ignores. But because his audience doesn't know what they don't know, he gets a pass. 

Ditto the complete melting of the icecaps during the dinosaur days. The meltwater flooded what we now know as Canada and the U.S. with a new ocean called the Western Interior Seaway, which remained for millions of years. It's why we find the fossils of sea creatures in Kansas. There is no other explanation for such warming than C02, especially since we know that the sun was actually weaker then, not stronger.

Google GREENLAND'S TEMPERATURE HAS RISEN 7 DEGREES SINCE 1991.

Global warming concentrates at the poles. Happer doesn't want to show you just how much far northern latitudes have warmed because he can't explain it any other way but via C02. Ask any Alaskan how much their climate has changed over the years and they'll give you an earful.

When the sun's last three cycles progressively weakened and all three Milankovitch Cycles are in cooling phases, we should NOT be warming like this.
author: SwiftlyTiltingPlanet

text:
¬†@CD Marshall¬† There is overwhelming evidence. No natural forces are at work to warm the planet now. None. Nada. Zip. No Milankovitch Cycles (they're in cooling phases), no increased solar output (output has dropped since 1980), no massive tectonic upheaval to spew billions of tons of C02 into the atmosphere. NOTHING. What we do have is a growing mass of anthropogenic C02 trapping heat in the atmosphere and radiating it back to earth.

Spectroscopic analysis clearly shows increasing heat passing through C02 in the atmosphere and radiating back to earth. Isotopic analysis clearly identifies the source of a substantial portion of this C02: the burning of fossil fuels. (Fossil fuel C02 has its own unique signature that differentiates it from natural C02).

C02 was proven to trap and re-radiate heat as far back as the 1800s. Since the Industrial Revolution we've emitted more and more C02 into the atmosphere. As the C02 levels rose so did the temperature. C02 and temperature have always tracked together throughout history.

As our lower atmosphere has warmed, the atmospheric layer just above it (stratosphere) has actually COOLED, according to NASA monitoring since 1978. That's an indication of heat prevented from escaping from below.

Neither the sun nor any warming source on earth can simultaneously warm the lower atmosphere while cooling the layer above it. Only a greenhouse effect can do that. Natural cycles also cannot explain why we're measuring less¬†heat¬†escaping to space at the precise wavelengths which¬†CO2¬†absorbs (Philipona 2004,¬†Wang 2009).

text: ¬†@SwiftlyTiltingPlanet¬†  That does not make him wrong. According to the climate experts back in the early 2000s, we were meant to have seen at least a 2m rise in sea levels by now. How did that 'science' turn out?
author: Andr√© Reloaded

text:
¬†@Andr√© Reloaded¬† Two meter rise in sea level by now? No climate scientist anywhere on this planet stated such a thing. Ever. Even when they were drunk. You're either scoffing at your own misinformation or listening to a crackpot. What they predicted by 2100 is a 12-18-inch rise, and so far we're on track to reach or exceed that mark. 

Happer isn't just wrong about a couple of things, he's wrong about a LOT of things. 
Unfortunately this forum doesn't allow links in posts otherwise I'd put up a bunch. I can, however, direct you to CLIMATE MISINFORMATION BY SOURCE: WILLIAM HAPPER
I'll also debunk some of his most common statements here. If you'd like the scientific papers that support my data, I'd be happy to let you know what they are and you can check them for yourself. 

1. ‚ÄúA doubling of C02 would do almost nothing.‚Äù

According to all of the scientific data and the official position of the IPCC, a doubling of C02 would raise global temperature 3C, more than enough to cause disaster. That‚Äôs in the short term. Over the long term, as ice sheets melt and reduce earth‚Äôs albedo, the temperature would rise as high as 6C, according to a study led by James Hansen. That would be catastrophic.

1. "Antarctic ice is probably growing." 

Just the opposite:  Google: "Greenland, Antarctica Melting Six Times Faster Than in the 1990s": 

Those who misrepresent the data will conflate land ice with sea ice. Sea ice returns in greater or lesser extent every winter and is merely a thin veneer. It does not reflect global warming like land ice does. Deniers will point to data showing that interior snowfall in Antarctica is increasing in some areas while they ignore the much greater melting happening along the shorelines and periphery. (Or they'll cherry-pick the now-famous Zwally study from 2015, which has been thoroughly discredited by more comprehensive studies that came before and after.)


As for his statements about the Arctic, Google NASA TIME LAPSE VIDEO OF MELTING ARCTIC ICE.  In fact, 95% of the Arctic's oldest, thickest ice has melted. 

"They said there's going to be this rapid global warming. It hasn't happened. Most of the warming was over by 1940." 

Happer apparently hasn't looked very hard. 19 of the last 20 years were the warmest on record. 2020 tied for first. Google any of the world's climate data centers for verification: NASA, NOAA, Berkeley Earth, the Japanese Meteorological Agency, the Hadley Met Office, etc.

Global warming concentrates at the poles, which is why average winter temperatures in places like Barrow, Alaska and Fairbanks have risen 9.8 degrees F and 8.1 degrees F respectively since 1949. Greenland's average temperature is up 7 degrees since 1991. Google Alaska Climate Trends and see for yourself. 

 "We're in a C02 famine. C02 was thousands of parts per million in the Cambrian."

We're not in a C02 famine. C02 was sky high in the Cambrian because of massive tectonic upheaval from two giant land masses colliding together. That's not NORMAL. The volcanic activity spewed trillions of tons of C02 into the atmosphere. In addition, no land plants existed to absorb out the extra C02 from the atmosphere. 

For the 800,000 years leading up to the Industrial Revolution, C02 levels remained below 300 ppm, and the planet, plants and people did just fine. Historically, C02 levels exceeding 300 ppm melt ice sheets and raise sea levels. Sea levels routinely rose dozens to over 200 feet in these C02-driven warm periods. That would be catastrophic for the millions of homes and businesses lining the world's shores today. 

"C02 is beneficial for plants." 

C02 is beneficial for plants only up to a point. Like water, too much of a good thing is too much of a good thing. Google THE EARTH STOPPED GETTING GREENER 20 YEARS AGO.
Happer won't share this but over 40% of our C02 emissions are NOT being absorbed by plants. They're simply being left behind to accumulate in the atmosphere. The reason they're not absorbing the extra C02 is because they are already SATURATED and are unable to keep up with our output. 

Happer also neglects to mention that while C02 is good for plants up to a point, the higher temperatures that come with that C02 are detrimental to plants, stunting their growth and even in some cases inhibiting the germination of seeds. In staple crops like rice, zinc, iron and protein content is diminished. In others, folate is lost. Some plants even lose parts of their natural defenses against insects, which devour them. text: The Milankovitch cycles drive the ice ages but his takes thousands of years and their effect is too weak to cause the shifts between glacials and interglacials on their own. Ice cores show us quite clearly that as orbital changes start the warm up phase after an ice age ocean temperatures rise, oceans release CO2 into the atmosphere. In turn, this release amplifies the warming trend, leading to yet more CO2 being released. Of course many prominent "deniers " try to cherry pick this information and claim CO2 "lags" temperature change and thus cannot be a driver but the science is clear. The major component of the Milankovitch cycles occurs with a period of 413,000 years. Other components have 95,000-year and 125,000-year cycles. They loosely combine into a 100,000-year cycle. This in no way explains the rapid warming the Earth is now seeing.

text:
¬†@Shawn Anderson¬† The reason all the things I stated matter is because William Happer is wrong. He's not just wrong about a couple of things, he's wrong about a LOT of things. 
Unfortunately this forum doesn't allow links in posts otherwise I'd put up a bunch. I can, however, direct you to CLIMATE MISINFORMATION BY SOURCE: WILLIAM HAPPER
I'll also debunk some of his most common statements here. If you'd like the scientific papers that support my data, I'd be happy to let you know what they are and you can check them for yourself. 

1. ‚ÄúA doubling of C02 would do almost nothing.‚Äù

According to all of the scientific data and the official position of the IPCC, a doubling of C02 would raise global temperature 3C, more than enough to cause disaster. That‚Äôs in the short term. Over the long term, as ice sheets melt and reduce earth‚Äôs albedo, the temperature would rise as high as 6C, according to a study led by James Hansen. That would be catastrophic.

1. "Antarctic ice is probably growing." 

Just the opposite:  Google: "Greenland, Antarctica Melting Six Times Faster Than in the 1990s": 

Those who misrepresent the data will conflate land ice with sea ice. Sea ice returns in greater or lesser extents every winter and is merely a thin veneer. It does not reflect global warming like land ice does. Deniers will point to data showing that interior snowfall in Antarctica is increasing in some areas while they ignore the much greater melting happening along the shorelines and periphery. (Or they'll cherry-pick the now-famous Zwally study from 2015, which has been thoroughly discredited by more comprehensive studies that came before and after.)


As for his statements about the Arctic, Google NASA TIME LAPSE VIDEO OF MELTING ARCTIC ICE.  In fact, 95% of the Arctic's oldest, thickest ice has melted. 

"They said there's going to be this rapid global warming. It hasn't happened. Most of the warming was over by 1940." 

Happer apparently hasn't looked very hard. 19 of the last 20 years were the warmest on record. 2020 tied for first. Google any of the world's climate data centers for verification: NASA, NOAA, Berkeley Earth, the Japanese Meteorological Agency, the Hadley Met Office, etc.

Global warming concentrates at the poles, which is why average winter temperatures in places like Barrow, Alaska and Fairbanks have risen 9.8 degrees F and 8.1 degrees F respectively since 1949. Greenland's average temperature is up 7 degrees since 1991. Google Alaska Climate Trends and see for yourself. 

 "We're in a C02 famine. C02 was thousands of parts per million in the Cambrian."

We're not in a C02 famine. C02 was sky high in the Cambrian because of massive tectonic upheaval from two giant land masses colliding together. That's not NORMAL. The volcanic activity spewed trillions of tons of C02 into the atmosphere. In addition, no land plants existed to absorb out the extra C02 from the atmosphere. 

For the 800,000 years leading up to the Industrial Revolution, C02 levels remained below 300 ppm, and the planet, plants and people did just fine. Historically, C02 levels exceeding 300 ppm melt ice sheets and raise sea levels. Sea levels routinely rose dozens to over 200 feet in these C02-driven warm periods. That would be catastrophic for the millions of homes and businesses lining the world's shores today. 

"C02 is beneficial for plants." 

C02 is beneficial for plants only up to a point. Like water, too much of a good thing is too much of a good thing. Google THE EARTH STOPPED GETTING GREENER 20 YEARS AGO.
Happer won't share this but over 40% of our C02 emissions are NOT being absorbed by plants. They're simply being left behind to accumulate in the atmosphere. Plants aren't absorbing it because they CAN'T; they're saturated and are unable to keep up with our output.

text:
¬†@Royston Clark¬† C02 helps plants grow, but only up to a point. Plants need a BALANCE of nutrients, not just C02. Too much of one or the other and they suffer deficits. With too much C02 rice loses a substantial portion of its zinc, iron and protein content. Some plants lose folate. Others lose their natural defenses against insects, which devour them. It's not nearly as simple as Happer lays out for you. 

There's no shortage of data showing that increasing temperatures can offset C02-driven growth. High heat not only prevents some seeds from germinating but also stunts growth, accelerates evaporation and produces water vapor deficits in the atmosphere. That means that the warmer atmosphere will actually draw out moisture from plants.

Google "MORE C02 IN THE ATMOSPHERE HURTS KEY PLANTS AND CROPS MORE THAN IT HELPS"   It's an easy to understand article from Yale University.

In addition to all the damage C02-driven warming creates (rising temperatures, melting icecaps, sea level rise, intensification of hurricanes, increases in extreme precipitation events, drought and wildfires), over 40% of our C02 emissions today are NOT being absorbed by plants. Those emissions are simply being left behind in the atmosphere to accumulate year after year, decade after decade. The crux of our problem, in fact, is that accumulation.


If plants needed that C02, why aren't they absorbing it? It's a simple answer: because they're already saturated and can no longer keep pace with our emissions. 

Happer shares none of this data but it's important for everybody to know. It's only with balanced information do we attain full understanding, helping us all to make better choices at the voting booth and in our daily lives.

author: Robert Price

text:
¬†@Robert Price¬† No consensus of scientists ever warned of an impending ice age. Outliers? Yes. The mainstream? No. 

The global cooling mythology of the 70s arose from a handful of scientists (not the majority, who were in fact warning about global warming even then) who worried about our ever-growing sulfate aerosol pollution problem. Sulfate aerosols, produced from burning coal, reflect sunlight and cool the planet the same way aerosols from volcanoes do. We were, in fact, in the middle of a slight cooling trend then, so the concern had some merit. 

Because aerosols were also causing premature deaths and massive health and lung problems worldwide, the U.S. decided to do something and passed the Clean Air Act (1970), which significantly reduced sulfate aerosol pollution. 

The clean-up was so effective that climate scientists can actually mark the time period of the 70s by the absence of the aerosol pollutants in ice cores. 

The long-lasting result was over $22 trillion in savings in health care, according to the EPA. Unfortunately, the drop in aerosols left C02 as the dominant pollutant, allowing it to continue to trap heat and raise global temperatures, just as MOST scientists in the 70s warned that it would.

author: Robert Price

text:
¬†@Robert Price¬† "The shoreline has been in roughly the same place." Have you measured? If so, do you take pains to measure at the exact same time of high tide each time? Or might you be off by an hour or two? Do you account for offshore winds? Do you live in part of the world experiencing glacial rebound, when the earth slowly bounces back from having a couple of miles of ice on top of it during the height of the last Ice Age? The process takes thousands of years and affects relative sea level measurements. 

Would you even notice if the high tide line changed by only 2 inches in 20 years? 

According to both NASA and European satellite data and worldwide tide gauges, average global sea level rise over the past five years has risen to 5mm per year. That's up from 1.5mm per year throughout most of the 20th century. You're not likely to notice that unless you pay really, really close attention and measure it out.

Any data gathered must be PROVEN with quantitative evidence. The evidence then must be peer reviewed, published, debated with other scientists and then replicated and corroborated by others. You can't cheat without being caught. And if you're caught, you lose your funding, your reputation and your career.

author: Robert Price

text:
¬†@Robert Price¬† Everyone knows that C02 is good for the planet, but only up to a point. Beyond that point it actually begins stripping plants of their nutrients. Rice, for example, loses substantial zinc, iron and protein content. Other plants lose folate. Still others, their natural defenses against insects, which devour them. It's not as simple as Happer lays out for you. Plants need a balanced combination of C02 and other nutrients, not a drowning in C02 alone.

Happer also leaves out the fact that C02-driven warming accelerates evaporation, which fills the atmosphere with increased water vapor which then works synergistically with C02 to increase warming further. Worse, all that extra water vapor must come down, and today it's coming down as increasing extreme precipitation events, according to worldwide data. A single extreme precipitation event can wipe out an entire year of a farmer's crops in one fell swoop while simultaneously washing away topsoils and fertilizer. . 

C02-driven warming also releases methane, another powerful greenhouse gas, from pent-up permafrost and helps to increase warming still further. As the ice sheets melt, the earth's reflection of sunlight (albedo) plummets, allowing more and more open land and ocean to absorb the sun's heat. That increases warming still further. 

In drier parts of the world, in areas that see few rain clouds pass, accelerated evaporation dries out vegetation and increases the incidence of drought, heatwaves and wildfires. None of these are good for the panet or good for plants.

High C02 levels in the past WERE NOT NORMAL. They were caused by massive tectonic upheaval from the break-up of continents. Such upheaval can spew trillions of tons of C02 into the atmosphere over the course of centuries, not just days or weeks.

252 million years ago the Siberian Traps released so much C02 from non-stop eruptions that equatorial temperature soared to 140 degrees, causing a mass extinction event known as the "Great Dying." Over 90% of all marine animals and 2 out of 3 land animals died out forever from the heat. 

Happer does not share this in his presentations, which is why I'm here. People need to hear ALL the information, not just part of it, in order to make informed decisions.

text:
¬†@Robert Price¬† Using a one hundred year data set for sea level rise is precisely how denier websites fool their audiences. Sea level remained stable at around 1.5mm throughout most of the 20th century and then jumped to 3mm in the 1990s, 4mm seven years ago, and 5mm over the past five years. That's according to the World Meteorological Organization. 

I never said rise was measured by shoreline distance. I assumed you were eyeballing it that way.
author: SwiftlyTiltingPlanet

text:
¬†@Robert Price¬† "No such thing as settled science" is the fossil fuel industry's favorite propaganda meme. Since I work in science and with climate data every day, let me give you the other side of that very tired argument.

It's settled science that the earth is round, is it not? That the earth orbits the sun? That the moon orbits the earth and affects our tides? That water is two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen? That the rhinovirus causes colds? That bacteria evolve? That antibiotics kill bacteria? That washing hands before surgery reduces the death rates of patients? That electricity is the flow of electrons? That dinosaurs died out about 65 million years ago? That humans did not exist during the time of the dinosaurs? That the atom can be split to produce energy? That the atmosphere is mostly made up of nitrogen, oxygen and argon? That the hippocampus plays a major role in memory? That humans who evolved near the equator have darker skin? That uranium is radioactive? That blood is formed in bone marrow? That mass creates gravity? Shall I go on? 

Evidence isn't subjective and no amount of rhetorical gymnastics changes that. We can descend into epistemic nihilism and secede from reality, believing there is no objective truth or independent criteria for determining what is real or false, or we can believe science, an empirical, verifiable reality that validates what we believe to be true. 

Spectroscopic analysis clearly shows heat passing through C02 in the atmosphere and radiating back to earth. That's an empirical fact. It won't change. It also reveals that C02 levels in the atmosphere are increasing. That's an empirical fact. It won't change. Isotopic analysis shows that a substantial amount of C02 in the atmosphere came directly from the burning of fossil fuels. That's an empirical fact. It won't change. Temperature has risen as our C02 accumulation has risen. Empirical fact. The rise of C02 began around the time of the Industrial Revolution. Empirical fact. The sun's last three cycles progressively weakened, yet we continued to warm anyway. Empirical fact. Earth's orbital eccentricty, axial tilt and precession are all in cooling phases, yet we continue to warm anyway. Empirical fact. As our lower atmosphere has warmed, the atmospheric layer just above it has COOLED, according to NASA monitring since 1978. That's evidence of the heat trapped below and prevented from filtering back into space. Natural cycles can't explain why satellites measure less¬†heat¬†escaping to space at the precise wavelengths which¬†CO2¬†absorbs (Philipona 2004,¬†Wang 2009). 

Neither the sun nor any warming force on earth can simultaneously warm the lower atmosphere while cooling the outer one. Only a greenhouse effect can do that. 

There is much in climate science that is indeed settled. Surely new facts will be added and some information refined but these won't change the empirically-based foundation of truth the new data will rest upon.

author: Mike May

text:
¬†@Mike May¬† I never said to trust AOC. As a science writer for nearly fifty years, I always advise people to ignore celebrities, politicians and crackpots and pay close attention to the science. 
That's why I'm here. 

Happer is refuted by the world's publishing climate scientists and the IPCC. You and everyone else on this forum really should question why before accepting anything he says at face value. 

I don't "hide under my bed" nor do I fear climate change. Nor do any climate scientists think the world is coming to an end. That's your own hyperbole, Mike.

Climate change, however, warrants concern, and for a lot of different reasons, which I'm sure you're well aware of by now.

No scientists swore the earth was flat. Religious people believed the world was flat because of references found in the Bible. Aristotle believed the sun revolved around the earth, not scientists. Science wasn't even a formal study until the establishment of the Royal Society in the 1600s. 

The ancient ignorant did not have tens of thousands of PhD-level scientists, hundreds of scientific institutes and academies of science and universitues as we do today. There was no formal training, no advanced degrees, no peer review process, no publishing of scientific papers. What the ignorant believed 500 years ago or a thousand years ago bears no relation to the incredible scholarship that we enjoy today. 

No physicians believed people got sick because of demons. Religious people did. The infancy of medicine didn't even begin until the 1800s, and even then knowledge remained primitive compared to what we know today. 

Nobody can predict weather more than 3 days out but you can predict climate thirty years from now. They're not the same. Weather is measured by the hour over limited regions. Climate is measured over 30-year spans over large areas of land.

text:
The "pollution problem" was worldwide, which is why the UK passed clean air legislation and the U.S. followed with the Clean Air Act in 1970. Millions were dying prematurely from lung and heart diseases then, specifically from sulfate aerosol pollution. According to the EPA, the U.S. alone saved over $22 trillion in health care costs just by passing the Clean Air Act. 

No consensus of climate scientists predicted climate apocalypse, either in the 70s, 80s or 90s. Crackpots? Yes. Outliers? Yes. But mainstream scientists? No. No consensus warned of imminent ice ages, coastal flooding or any of the other mythological nonsense that right media peddles to discredit climate science. 

40 years ago the scientists predicted that temperatures would continue rising now. They were right. 19  of the last 20 years were the warmest on record. 2020 tied for first. They predicted the icecaps would melt. They are, at rates unprecedented in recorded history. They predicted sea level would rise. It is. The global average is up from 1.5mm throughout most of the 20th century to 5mm per year now. They predicted that hurricanes would intensify. They have. Category 1 and 2 storms have diminished while cat 4 and 5 storms have taken their place. They predicted extreme precipitation events would increase. They have. WORLDWIDE. They predicted droughts and wildfires would intensify. They have. 

William Happer is refuted by 97% of publishing climate scientists, the IPCC, and the 170 scientific institutions who publicly endorse the consensus findings. He is not a climate scientist, has no formal climate science training, and has written no climate change papers. His specialty is optics.

text:
William Happer is refuted by 97% of publishing climate scientists, the IPCC, and the 170 scientific institutions who publicly endorse the consensus findings. He is not a climate scientist, has no formal climate science training, and has written no climate change papers. His specialty is optics.

The Wikipedia disclaimer is fully justified. See CLIMATE MISINFORMATION BY SOURCE: WILLIAM HAPPER

The slight cooling in the 1970s was indeed caused by sulfate aerosols, from burning coal, but we cleared a substantial portion of those aerosols when we passed the Clean Air Act in 1970. The clearing allowed C02 to resume as the dominant atmospheric pollutant and continue its warming trend, just as the vast majority of mainstream scientists predicted that it would. 

No climate scientists anywhere on this planet said that all the icecaps would be melted now or that coastlines would be flooded today. None. Nada. Zip. Not even when they were drunk. Neither did Al Gore. You're scoffing at your own misinformation. 

Climate scientists have been predicting for over 40 years that sea levels would rise steadily, which they have done. Throughout most of the 20th century, sea level rise hovered around 1.5mm per year. In the 90s it jumped to 3mm per year. Over the past five years, it has been 5mm per year, according to the World Meteorological Organization. It's why high tide flooding along the American northeast coast has risen 140% in the last 20 years alone, according to NOAA. It's up an astonishing 190% along the southeast. 

The term "climate change" has been in use in scientific journals since the 1950s. Nobody changed it from "global warming." They are two different terms. Global warming denotes warming, of course. But "climate change" denotes warming and ALL OF ITS EFFECTS: changes in air and ocean currents, migration of the snow/rain line, intensification of hurricanes, increases in extreme precipitation events, droughts, wildfires, etc. 

The amusing thing about your misinformation is that it was Republican political strategist Frank Luntz who brought the "climate change" term into the mainstream. In a now famous 2002 memo to Republican candidates, he warned them to never use "global warming" in a speech because he thought it sounded too scary. He urged them to use "climate change" instead. And they did. In fact, Republicans repeated "climate change" so often that it was quickly adopted by middle America and has ever since been in common usage. LOOK IT UP.

text: Venice holds back the water for first time in 1,200 years Julia Buckley Published 5th October 2020 Venice, Italy (CNN) ‚Äî Sebastian Fagarazzi is used to moving his belongings around. As a Venetian who lives on the ground floor, every time the city faces acqua alta -- the regular flooding caused by high tides -- he must raise everything off the floor, including furniture and appliances, or risk losing it. But on October 3, with a 135-centimeter (53-inch) high tide forecast -- which would normally see around half the city under various levels of water -- when the flood sirens went off, he did nothing. "I had faith," he says. Saturday was the first acqua alta of the season for Venice. It was also the day when, after decades of delays, controversy and corruption, the city finally trialled its long-awaited flood barriers against the tide.
author: Imminent Threat

text: Polar Bears Really Are Starving Because of Global Warming, Study Shows This article is from National Geographic. February 1, 2018  New science sheds more light on recent controversy over how much the large carnivores are being impacted by melting sea ice. Millions have seen the heart-wrenching video of a polar bear clinging to life, its white hair limply covering its thin, bony frame. Shot by Paul Nicklen and Cristina Mittermeier of the nonprofit group Sea Legacy, and published on National Geographic in early December, the video ignited a firestorm of debate about what scientists know, and don‚Äôt know, about the impacts of global warming on polar bears. Without examining the bear in the video‚Äîthought to have died‚Äîit‚Äôs impossible to know for sure what ailed that individual, but now scientists have published new findings that shed more light on the risk to the species overall. Because of melting sea ice, it is likely that more polar bears will soon starve, warns a new study that discovered the large carnivores need to eat 60 percent more than anyone had realized. Turns out they are high-energy beasts, burning through 12,325 calories a day‚Äîdespite sitting around most of the time, according to a unique metabolic analysis of wild bears published Thursday in Science.

text:
¬†@mikeymike1001¬† Did you fact-check the video? You should. It's a veritable Mulligan Stew of inaccuracies, misrepresentations, lies of omission and outdated material. 

A few examples of updated info: Solar panels generate the energy required to build themselves in one to two years of operation, depending on the type of panel and location and their lifetime is about 30 years; large wind turbines in three to 12 months, depending on size of turbines and location, and their lifetime is 25 to 30 years,‚Äù says Associate Professor Mark Diesendorf, an energy systems and sustainability expert at the University of New South Wales. This is backed up by research from the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) on the degradation of solar panels over time. According to NREL's data, solar panels have a median degradation rate of 0.5% per year, signifying that a median panel still produces at 90% of its capability after 20 years. In fact, most solar panels these days come with warranties of at least 20 years‚Äîtwice as long as the service life that Planet of the Humans states. 

According to Oregon State University, the average energy payback for a large wind turbine is eight months. In evaluating life-cycle greenhouse gas emissions, the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) found that solar PV emitted an average of 45 grams per kWh, compared to 500 grams per kWh for natural gas and 1,001 grams per kWh for coal. In reaching this finding, NREL examined 2,100 published references, subjecting them to three rounds of critical reviews by experts. "That renewable energy generation generates the same amount of emissions as fossil fuel generation simply isn‚Äôt true: even an old meta-analysis of studies on wind farms, produced back in 2010 when turbines were far less efficient than they are now, found that an average turbine generates 20 times more energy than it takes to produce." ----Forbes Magazine

The Union of Concerned Scientists conducted a two-year study and found that electric vehicles over their lifetimes produce far fewer emisions than gasoline cars, even in states that produce some of their energy from coal. (Other studies show that they're also cheaper to own over their lifespan, due to less maintenance and fewer moving parts. According to Energy.gov, on a national average, it costs less than half as much to travel the same distance in an EV than a conventional vehicle.) Other studies, including those by the International Council for Clean Transportation and the IVL Swedish Environmental Research Institute find that as of 2019, lifecycle emissions for electric cars were about 3 times lower than for conventional cars. Where batteries are produced makes a big difference. A battery produced in China, with plants powered with coal, will create far more emissions than the standard Tesla battery manufactured with renewable energy in its Nevada plant. 

Iowa now gets 42% of its power from wind. Kansas gets 41%. Oklahoma gets 35%. The Dakotas 25%. Even Maine gets 21%. This leap forward was not a reality 20 years ago. Where will it be 20 years from now? Wind turbines in the UK now produce enough electricity to power 11.5 million homes. Denmark gets 50% of its power from wind. So does South Australia. Scotland produces twice the wind power they need to light ALL of its homes. 

The video did not tell you ANY of the success stories. Instead it focused solely on outdated information. Always seek rebuttals before jumping to conclusions. 

‚ÄúPlanet of the Humans is wildly unscientific, outdated, full of falsehoods, and benefits fossil fuel industry promoters and climate deniers.‚Äù ---the Nation 

I'd love to link you to the endless rebuttals to the film but the Hillsdale College forum doesn't allow links in posts. Simply Google PLANET OF THE HUMANS DEBUNKED and you'll find plenty to chew on.
author: SwiftlyTiltingPlanet

author: mikeymike1001

text:
¬†@mikeymike1001¬† Unless you've been living under a rock, you know the Texas power outage wasn't caused by wind and solar. ALL of their power sources froze up: oil, gas, coal, nuclear. 

Wind turbines in Iowa don't freeze. They don't in the Dakotas or in Maine or in Denmark. That's because they're all winterized. Texas was too huffy about federal regulations to do as advised and went their own way and as a result NOTHING was winterized. The Republican theology of deregulation has placed their heads so far up in the clouds that they neglected to put in even the most trivial of safeguards. 

Electrical grids today tap a variety of power sources. Wind and solar are incredibly cheap sources of supplemental power. They are, in fact, the cheapest sources of energy on the planet now. No one at this juncture is expecting them to carry the entire load, although new battery technology on the horizon will be storing their energy for up to days at a time to solve the intermittency challenge. Liquid air batteries, for example, distill nitrogen from the air, employ no toxic compounds, are economical to build, and deliver far more power for longer durations than lithium ion batteries.) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tMLu9Dtw9yI  

Until all the new promising technology develops, the ony wise way forward is with a variety of power sources; wind, solar, hydro, advanced nuclear, and gas and oil on a diminished basis. There is a reasonable middle ground here.
author: SwiftlyTiltingPlanet

text:
No climate scientists ever said we'd be under 50 feet of ice now. You completely manufactured that hyperbole from your own imagination. 

The global cooling scare of the 70s arose from a handful of scientists (not the majority, who were in fact warning about global warming even then) who worried about our ever-growing sulfate aerosol pollution problem. Sulfate aerosols, produced from burning coal, reflect sunlight and cool the planet the same way aerosols from volcanoes do. We were, in fact, in the middle of a slight cooling trend then, so the concern had some merit. 

Because aerosols were also causing premature deaths and massive health and lung problems worldwide, the U.S. decided to do something and passed the Clean Air Act (1970), which significantly reduced sulfate aerosol pollution. The clean-up was so effective that climate scientists can actually mark the time period of the 70s by the absence of the aerosol pollutants in ice cores. 

The long-lasting result was over $22 trillion in savings in health care, according to the EPA. Unfortunately, the drop in aerosols left C02 as the dominant pollutant, allowing it to continue to trap heat and raise global temperatures, just as MOST scientists in the 70s warned that it would.

text: ¬†@Garo Sama¬† Learn what the Dome C ice cores are, Garo.  They recorded 800,000 years of climate changes, and they show natural cycles of temperature and CO2 concentration during that time.  According to those natural cycles we should be entering a cooling phase, but instead, we're warming up.  The cores also show the CO2 increase trails the temperature increase in a natural cycle, but nowadays the CO2 increase is leading the temperature increase.  We're not in a natural cycle anymore, and the only thing that's changed is the proportion of atmospheric gasses - which human activity caused.
author: Jasmine Lindros

text:
¬†@Garo Sama¬† All three Milankovitch Cycles (changes in earth's orbit, axial tilt and precession) are in COOLING phases now. Recurring over thousands of years, the cycles alter how much direct sunlight the earth receives and where. They're responsible for triggering and ending ice ages and warm interglacials.

The only other major warming factor is massive tectonic upheaval, which in the past spewed trillions of tons of C02 into the atmosphere. We have no such upheaval today.

We also know from spectroscopic analysis that heat is increasingly radiating back from C02 in the atmosphere and is being blocked from filtering out into the stratosphere and beyond. We also know from isotopic analysis that a large portion of this C02 came directly from the burning of fossil fuels.
author: SwiftlyTiltingPlanet

text: ¬†@Jasmine Lindros¬† Exactly. Not only is C02 leading temperature today but Shakun et al (2013) and Parrenin et al (2013) cast serious doubt on the "temperature leads C02" trope of the past. What was true in Antarctica, apparently, was not true for the rest of the globe.

text: A great scientist but not a speaker. He omitted the total difference between climate and weather, and made no mention of the Earth‚Äôs magnetic shield. No mention of the forces that vary climate. The Earth‚Äôs spin, wobble, tilt and orbital shape and orbital tilt all vary in their own cycles. Milutin Milankovitch, a brilliant Serbian mathematician combined the cycles of the spin, tilt, wobble and orbital shape into one big compounded super cycle which bears his name. No mention of how the Milankovitch cycle fits our periodic ice ages when their is ice on Earth and the  much larger interglacial periods when there is no ice at all. In the very long time, our climate zones are drastically changed by continental shift (Australia is moving 1 to 3 inches a year and rotating east, separating from the plate that it shares with India). That shifting of the crust‚Äôs plates create mountains and valleys and re-locates vast land masses. Part of Canada was once equatorial. He did not explain that the climates (plural) are always changing, so the blather about stopping climate change is at best hysteria due to ignorance and at worst, lunacy or mendacity. There is no data supporting the claim that 97% of the world‚Äôs scientists agree with this horrific fraud, the number 97 was plucked out of a seminar and transmogrified into a 97% consensus. No meeting of anything in history accounted for 100% of scientists and Prof. Happer correctly said that science is not based on votes, or consensus, it is based on data correctly gathered and correctly analyzed then exposed to ruthless criticism. The dreadful thing is that due to funding pressures on universities and other science establishments gave been blackmailed into support for this fraud or loose funding and in the case of once great science journals, the fear of lost advertising revenue has turned them into a fools‚Äô chorus. We have returned to the medieval times when dogma made scientists fear for their lives. Galileo Galilea was tried for heresy, not for what he claimed,  but because what he claimed was counter to Catholic teaching when the church knew the truth very well. With its priceless library, they knew for instance that an ancient Greek measured the circumference of Earth, which was basically a sphere, and not a flat plate. Great scientists, some Nobel prize winners, have been silenced and even expelled from universities for wanting to publish or speak about the truth. The atmospheric CO2 is not uniform, it varies according to climate, topography, elevation and life activity. It does however hover around 400ppm. The good prof. touched on CO2 being plant food, but missed the opportunity to tell that modern computer controlled greenhouse agriculture pumps CO2 into the greenhouse up to 1000 to 1200 parts per million (ppm), to produce crops that are healthier, grow faster, produce more and better food and are more disease resistant. He did not reveal that the so-called hockey stick graph was simply a ‚ÄòWhat-if‚Äù graph manipulated to falsely show that CO2  levels in air rise before the temperature rises, whereas physics shows the reverse. Both oxygen and CO2 dissolve in water, nitrogen (70% of the atmospheric ) does not. If you heat water, the dissolved gasses bubble out, anyone who has watched water heated in a kitchen knows that. CO2 rises as a result of oceans heating, not the fraudulently claimed reverse. Our seas and oceans have warmer and cooler periods year round, that helps disperse the heat load as do the winds. Most of us hear from the weather channels about La Nina and El Nino cycles in the Pacific,  but there are others in the Indian ocean, up the west coast of North America, The Gulf stream with its Atlantic Conveyor and many more. Our climate is always changing, it has done so for over 4 billion years, it is due to complex cosmic and local forces beyond our control, and anyone who thinks that we can stop climates (plural!!!) from changing are either ignorant, gullible, scared or malevolent.

text:
I have not heard this issue.

Crude oil is distilled into several fractions.  One barrel of oil is not refined into one barrel of gasoline.    Instead it is refined into gasoline, jet fuel (kerosene), diesel fuel, lubricants, raw materials for electrical insulation, certain road pavings, car tires, etc.

Now, we are going to electric cars, which means using less gasoline, the same number of tires, the same amount of road paving raw materials, more electrical insulation and so forth.  

I don't understand how we can cut our refining of crude oil in response to less gasoline use, the same use of tires and other petroleum products, and increased use some petroleum products such as insulation.

If we must maintain or increase our refining of crude oil to maintain the supply of tires and other petroleum products, what happens to the unused gasoline fraction from the crude oil distillation?  How does conversation to electric cars have any hope of decreasing atmospheric carbon dioxide?

Oil industry funding paid out to protect trillions in assets is not remotely the same as funding provided to gather data. Happer doesn't have to PROVE his data to satisfy the fossil fuel industry. Scientists do. They must prove their data with their funders, with their peers and with the public.

Funding is given to scientists to gather information, not prove climate change. Conclusions are reached after the data is analyzed, not before, and funders have no say in the outcomes nor their interpretations. No scientist can simply make things up to satisfy anyone's "agenda." Any data gathered must be PROVEN with quantitative evidence. The evidence then must be peer reviewed, published, debated with other scientists and then replicated and corroborated by others. You can't cheat without being caught. And if you're caught, you lose your funding, your reputation and your career.

And the scientific papers of the remaining 3% have all been debunked. This forum doesn't allow links in posts so Google the following: THOSE 3% OF SCIENTIFIC PAPERS THAT DENY CLIMATE CHANGE? A REVIEW FOUND THEM ALL FLAWED. 

If you haven't been formally trained in climate science, have never worked in the field, have published no papers in the field, you are hardly qualified to refute those who do. Nevertheless you have every right to submit your scientific paper for publication, and many have. And just as many have been shot down by the evidence. 

Deniers like to cite Freeman Dyson as an "expert" on climate change because he objected to the findings. "I'm just saying I don't understand it, and neither does anybody else," he told Yale Environment 360 in an interview. One who admits he knows little about the science is not a credible debunker of that science. Dyson admitted that he didn't even know what caused the Ice Ages, although climate scientists clearly do. Asking Dyson about climate change is the equivalent of asking the local rocket scientist for advice on your upcoming heart transplant. A brilliant scientist in one field is not necessarily a brilliant scientist in another.

text:

No. Some of these are your own misinformation and lack of research, like New York being underwater by 2019 and the Arctic free of ice by 2013, among others.

Al Gore quoted several scientists, who gave RANGES when the Arctic would open, with his most famous prediction being this: A "75% chance that the Arctic would be free of ice in SOME SUMMER MONTHS (and only in summer)" somewhere between 2013 and 2030. See the video below. The fact is that the Arctic is melting away at rates unprecdented in recorded history and is right on track to make that prediction come true. Here's the video clip. Start at the two minute mark and listen carefully: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MsioIw4bvzI

And James Hansen was the one who allegedly said the West Side Highway would be underwater now. Only he DIDN"T. A reporter asked him what the West Side Highway would look like in 40 years (not 20 as is popularly misquoted across the internet) IF C02 LEVELS DOUBLED.

40 years have not passed and C02 levels have not doubled. However, Queens, New York is experiencing regular high tide flooding. Google it. 

Hurricanes have, in fact, intensified, according to all the latest data, with fewer category 1 and 2 storms and more cat 4 and 5s. 

Since 1995 there have been 19 above-normal Atlantic hurricane seasons, as measured by NOAA‚Äôs Accumulated Cyclone Energy (ACE) Index. So while there aren‚Äôt necessarily more Atlantic hurricanes than before, those that form are getting stronger. February 1, 2018  New science sheds more light on recent controversy over how much the large carnivores are being impacted by melting sea ice. Millions have seen the heart-wrenching video of a polar bear clinging to life, its white hair limply covering its thin, bony frame. Shot by Paul Nicklen and Cristina Mittermeier of the nonprofit group Sea Legacy, and published on National Geographic in early December, the video ignited a firestorm of debate about what scientists know, and don‚Äôt know, about the impacts of global warming on polar bears.
