text: ¬†@Garo Sama¬† Venice holds back the water for first time in 1,200 years Julia Buckley Published 5th October 2020 Venice, Italy (CNN) ‚Äî Sebastian Fagarazzi is used to moving his belongings around. As a Venetian who lives on the ground floor, every time the city faces acqua alta -- the regular flooding caused by high tides -- he must raise everything off the floor, including furniture and appliances, or risk losing it. But on October 3, with a 135-centimeter (53-inch) high tide forecast -- which would normally see around half the city under various levels of water -- when the flood sirens went off, he did nothing. "I had faith," he says. Saturday was the first acqua alta of the season for Venice. It was also the day when, after decades of delays, controversy and corruption, the city finally trialled its long-awaited flood barriers against the tide.

INCREASED WARMING: 
19 of the last 20 years were the warmest on record. 2020 is tied for first.  Record warm temperatures are now outpacing record cold ones by a 2 to 1 margin. 

SCORE: Al Gore 

HEAT CONCENTRATED TOWARD THE POLES: Average winter temperature for Anchorage and Fairbanks, Alaska has risen an astonishing 8 degrees F since mid 20th century. Greenland's average temperature is up 7 degrees since 1991.

MORE EXTENSIVE HEAT WAVES: Heatwaves have increased in duration and intensity. The heatwave involving 17 countries in 2018 was the largest heat event in history. 

SCORE: Al Gore 

ICECAPS AND GLACIERS WILL MELT: The Arctic, Greenland and Antarctica are all melting at rates unprecedented in recorded history. So are more than 90% of the world's glaciers. In fact, the melt rate is accelerating. 

SCORE: Al Gore 

SEA LEVEL WILL RISE: According to the latest bulletin from the World Meteorological Organization, average global sea level rise over the past five years was 5mm per year, up from 4mm six years ago, 3mm in the 1990s and 1.5mm throughout most of the 20th century. It is indeed rising and it is accelerating.

HIGH TIDE FLOODING WILL INCREASE: According to NOAA, high tide flooding along the American southeast coast has risen 190% in just 20 years. The northeast is up 140%. 

SCORE: Al Gore 

EXTREME PRECIPITATION WILL INCREASE: According to EPA statistics,  extreme downpours have risen 55% in the northeast. They've risen 30-40% in the south, midwest and northern states. Similar increases in extreme precipitation are being seen around the world.

HURRICANES WILL INCREASE: They actually haven‚Äôt increased but they have strengthened. Since 1995 there have been 19 above-normal Atlantic hurricane seasons, as measured by NOAA‚Äôs Accumulated Cyclone Energy (ACE) Index. ACE calculates the intensity of a hurricane season by combining the number, wind speed and duration of each tropical cyclone. That‚Äôs the largest stretch of above-normal seasons on record. So while there aren‚Äôt necessarily more Atlantic hurricanes than before, those that form are getting stronger, with more Category 4 and 5 events.

THE GULF STREAM WILL SLOW  The latest data shows that the Gulf Stream is clearly slowing down.

text:
The Ice Ages come and go by Milankovitch Cycles, changes in earth's orbit, axial tilt and precession. The cycles, which recur every several thousand years, expose more or less of the earth to direct sunlight.  Every 100,000 years, for example, Jupiter and Saturn's gravity nudges the earth slightly closer in its orbit around the sun. Roughly every 40,000 years axial tilt also changes how much direct sunlight falls on the northern hemisphere. No humans required.

Today all three Milankovitch Cycles are in cooling phases, yet we continue to warm. Our C02 emissions have simply overpowered nature's natural progression.

text:
¬†@Gerald Blackburn¬† The U.S. Supreme Court ruled years ago that C02 is indeed a pollutant. Happer won't call it that because as the head of the C02 Coalition he was paid by the oil industry to encourage the public to use MORE fossil fuels. You're being bamboozled by marketing. 

Any substance that causes environmental damage is a "pollutant." C02 in EXCESS causes damage,  not only by warming the planet but by melting ice sheets, raising sea levels, intensifying hurricanes, droughts and wildfires, and increasing extreme precipitation events.


According to investigations by Drexel University and the Union of Concerned Scientists, the fossil fuel industry has funded nearly 100 climate change denial organizations, front groups, PR men (like Happer) and websites. All work synergistically as part of a marketing juggernaut to sow seeds of doubt about climate change. 

Everyone knows C02 is good for plants, Gerald, but only up to a point. Exposed to too much C02 staple crops like rice lose substantial amounts of their zinc, iron and protein content. Others lose folate. Still others lose part of their natural defenses against insects, which devour them. C02 in optimum, balanced combinations with other nutrients is what helps plants.

Most salient here is that over 40% of our yearly C02 emissions are NOT being absorbed by plants. Plants have already reached C02 saturation and are now unable to absorb our excess. That surplus is simply being left to accumulate in the atmosphere. Decade after decade. Century after century. The accumulation, alas, is the crux of our trouble. 

I'd be happy to give you the evidence for anthropogenically-generated warming. Just let me know. Keep in mind, though, that this forum doesnt allow links in posts and will remove any posts that contain them. I can direct you to information but I won't be able to make it easy by providing links.

A recent study published in Nature outlines research by a team of Yale University and University of Southhampton scientists. text: Climate naysayers have long upheld CO2 fertilization as evidence that humans are doing the planet a solid by pumping 40 billion tons of fossil carbon into the air every year. It‚Äôs an argument that makes sense superficially, but falls apart as soon as you start to unpack it. The land and ocean cannot absorb all the extra CO2 we are emitting. About 40% of the additional CO2 we are emitting is absorbed. The rest remains in the atmosphere, consequently, atmospheric CO2 is at its highest level in 10‚Äôs of thousands of years. (A natural change of 100ppm normally takes 5,000 to 20,000 years. The recent increase of has taken just 120 years). CO2 is a greenhouse gas, and the simple truth is greenhouse gases allow short wavelength solar radiation to pass through the atmosphere unimpeded. As the Sun warms up Earth‚Äôs surface, longer wavelength thermal radiation is reflected back into the atmosphere. Some of this thermal radiation passes into space, some of the radiation is absorbed and some is reflected back to Earth. More CO2 means more thermal radiation is reflected back to Earth and this causes the temperature on Earth to rise. It is all explained through science.

‚Äã¬†@S9ngs Hollingworth¬†   The global cooling scare of the 70s arose from a handful of outlier scientists (not the majority, who were in fact warning about global warming even then) who worried about our ever-growing sulfate aerosol pollution problem. Sulfate aerosols, produced from burning coal, reflect sunlight and cool the planet the same way aerosols from volcanoes do. We were, in fact, in the middle of a slight cooling trend then, so the concern had some merit. 

Because aerosols were also causing premature deaths and massive health and lung problems worldwide, the U.S. decided to do something and passed the Clean Air Act (1970), which significantly reduced sulfate aerosol pollution. The clean-up was so effective that climate scientists can actually mark the time period of the 70s by the absence of the aerosol pollutants in ice cores. 

The long-lasting result was over $22 trillion in savings in health care, according to the EPA. Unfortunately, the drop in aerosols left C02 as the dominant pollutant, allowing it to continue to trap heat and raise global temperatures, just as MOST scientists in the 70s warned that it would.

text:
NASA HAS BEEN WARNING OF A GRAND SOLAR MINIMUM (GSM) FOR THE PAST DECADE
SEPTEMBER 15, 2020 CAP ALLON
NASA has been warning of a Grand Solar Minimum (GSM) for the past decade-or-so, and says the sun could be in a GSM phase for 10% to 30% of the time. However, the modern AGW dogma has stopped the agency short of drawing a connection between reduced solar output and ‚Äúice age‚Äù type weather events.

The sun‚Äôs output is not constant‚Äìdespite what the IPCC would have you believe. Its emissions are modulated by its planets (namely conjunctions of Saturn, Jupiter, Earth and Venus) due to the interacting gravitational effects, and also by internal mechanisms.

NASA says it is able to predict sunspot numbers for the next cycle from magnetic activity of the sun hundreds of thousands of kilometres below its surface. For many years now (since at least 2010), the agency has believed that this deep activity is so weak that there may be very few sunspots in the next solar cycle (25): ‚ÄúIndeed, the sun could be on the threshold of a mini-Maunder event right now. There is evidence of a long-term weakening trend in the magnetic field strength of sunspots. Matt Penn and William Livingston of the National Solar Observatory predict that by the time Solar Cycle 25 arrives, magnetic fields on the sun will be so weak that few if any sunspots will be formed. Independent lines of research involving helioseismology and surface polar fields tend to support their conclusion‚Äù.

text:
¬†@Jim Gollagher¬† Take his graph at the 25:00 mark. He notes that a doubling of C02 would not double temperature. He's right. It wouldn't. But no climate scientist has ever said that it would.  In fact, we know what a doubling would do. A doubling of C02 would raise global temperature by at least 3C, which is more than enough to create disaster. This is the number that IPCC scientists and the very latest data agree on.

What Happer frequently neglects to include in his projections are the feedback effects that C02 triggers.C02-driven warming, in fact,  accelerates evaporation, which fills the atmosphere with additional water vapor which, itself a greehouse gas, then works synergistically to warm the planet more than C02 could do on its own. Methane, another powerful greenhouse gas, is also released from pent-up permafrost. Like water vapor, it works with C02 to increase warming beyond what C02 could do on its own. 

These are short range temperature changes. Long range changes, by contrast, could go as high as 6C, according to a study led by James Hansen. As time goes on, more and more of the ice sheets melt, reducing sun-reflecting albedo, and exposing more land and ocean to absorb (instead of reflect) sunlight. This is, in fact, one of the most powerful synergistic warming agents to work with C02. 

Here are some other debunkings of Happer. Be sure to click on the links so you can explore each of his pieces of misinformation in more detail. https://skepticalscience.com/William_Happer_arg.htm
author: SwiftlyTiltingPlanet

text:
¬†@Jim Gollagher¬† Everyone knows C02 is good for plants. But only up to a point. Like water, too much of a good thing is too much of a good thing. Numerous university studies show that higher C02 diminishes staple crops like rice and wheat of their zinc, iron and protein content. Some plants lose part of their natural defenses against insects, which devour them. Other plants lose folate. It's not as simple as it appears or as the fossil fuel industry would have you believe with their "C02 is good for plants" marketing blitz. 

An important point to keep in mind is that the world's plants are not absorbing our excess C02. We know by isotopic analysis that over 40% of our emissions are not being absorbed by plants or other natural sinks, but are being left in the atmosphere to accumulate, year after year. If plants needed more C02, why aren't they absorbing that excess? The thinking is that they have simply reached their saturation point and can't keep up with our over-supply.

A few years ago a NASA satellite surveyed a distinct new "greening" of the earth, which  scientists chalked up to C02 fertilization of plants. A few years later they looked at the data again and realized they had misjudged. On closer inspection, a substantial portion of that new "greening" was due to the planting of billions of trees by China, India and Europe. (China alone planted 66 billion trees!)

text: A great physical scientist with a vital message, but not so great a historian. Invoking the Crusades as his historical analog to the attitudes of climate alarmists was sophomoric. The First Crusade was called in 1095 to answer a call for military help from the Byzantine emperor, who was under attack by the Seljuks, and to bring Jerusalem under Christian rule again. In four years, it accomplished both these goals. Hardly a good example of misguided and futile sacrifice. Yes, the Crusaders believed God willed them to help their eastern brothers who were under attack. So? Was that so bad, to try to do God‚Äôs will, i.e., the right thing? The alarmists certainly need to be thwacked, but weak historical comparisons aren‚Äôt the way to do it.

GLACIERS WILL MELT

SEA LEVEL WILL RISE AND ACCELERATE
Sea level rise throughout the 20th century hovered around 1.5mm per year. Over the past five years, according to the WMO, it was 5mm per year.

HIGH TIDE FLOODING WILL INCREASE
According to NOAA, high tide flooding along the American northeast has increased 140% in the last 20 years. It's up 190% along the southeast.

EXTREME PRECIPITATION EVENTS WILL INCREASE
According to the EPA, extreme precipitation events along the American northeast are up over 50%. Along the south, midwest and northern plains, 30-40%. These events are also increasing worldwide.

text:
An excellent presentation thanks with real science, not the empirical perceptions of Michael Mann. 

Spending money on climate change is quixotic tilting at windmills. Carbon taxes are folly. Deforestation is the problem. Reforestation or land set aside the solution. I‚Äôve witnessed it with my own eyes. 

Born and bred in Africa I witnessed much of the climate change in Zimbabwe since David Livingstone, as forests were cut down for grain and tobacco cultivation and 80% of the land changed to grassland and semi-desert. The EU land set aside restores nature‚Äôs powers over the climate, fixing carbon dioxide and stabilising temperatures and rainfall.  Why else is earth‚Äôs atmospheric carbon dioxide just 0.04% when it straddles between Venus and Mars orbits each planet with atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations in excess of 90%? Carbon dioxide is not the demon, it is plant food and plants work for us providing us with food and controlling our climate to be most favourable for life. Carbon dioxide and fossil fuels are just side actors, just like police cars and ambulances are to accident scenes. Just because police cars and ambulances are present at every accident scene does not mean that they caused them. The same with carbon dioxide and fossil fuels, they were mere agents of deforestation but deforestation was the cause of environmental changes. 

Global carbon dioxide concentration increases have been shown to lag global temperature increases which means carbon dioxide concentration cannot be the cause of temperature increases. Carbon dioxide concentration in thinly-populated agrarian Zimbabwe was not the agent of such a large climate change in the country. Global carbon dioxide concentration lagged global temperature increases because it raised ocean temperatures to expel dissolved carbon dioxide. Thus carbon dioxide concentration is to temperature, is what the police car is to road accidents. Both lag the incident. 

So the solution to gaining control over our environment is strengthening nature. 

The first method can be used by you personally to indirectly alter the climate for the better. Change to a keto or paleo diet and minimise your carbohydrate intake. Eat food that comes from trees and eat dairy products that come from dairy cows and goats that will improve the ground under the trees. This will not only improve your health and eliminate T2D, but more importantly it will incentivise farmers to plant trees which bind soils and provide nuts and seeds for your keto diet. If you choose a high carbohydrate diet, farmers will respond by cutting down forests to grow grain for your food. So by altering your food intake to a keto or paleo diet, you alter the food chain and thus ultimately the climate. 

See the best keto diet here https://youtu.be/gxLSxt2IKiQ

The second (macro) solution can bring about climate improvement is as follows. 

1) Build plant factories to feed 7.8 billion people and liberate land and water for forests
https://youtu.be/dnCQuwCtqJg
https://youtu.be/qGyAeqdkkbw

4) Use agrivoltaics to turn deserts into meadows with solar panels

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haida_Salmon_Restoration_Corporation

Be positive. Be useful. Don‚Äôt be misanthropic with the debunked carbon dioxide nonsense. Help flora and fauna control climate and don‚Äôt demonise plant food.

author: mark boggs

text:
¬†@mark boggs¬† You should have given me something tougher than his graph. It's what Happer leaves out that fools you, Mark. The latest study (Sherwood et al) puts climate sensitivity at 3 C or slightly higher. That's in agreement with the IPCC standard asessment. 3C is more than enough to cause global disaster. 

What Happer usually neglects to do is calculate in warming's feedback effects. C02-driven warming accelerates evaporation, which fills the atmosphere with additional water vapor which then acts synergistically with C02 to raise temperatures higher than what C02 could do itself. 
Methane is also released from long pent-up permafrost which, like water vapor, works in tandem with C02 to trap even more heat and raise temperatures still further. 

This is in the short range. Over the long range, climate sensitivity is even higher than 3C and possibly as high as 6C, according to a study led by James Hansen. As warming continues more and more of the ice sheets melt away, which reduces albedo and allows much greater solar insolation in the oceans and in the land which then no longer reflect sunlight but absorb it.

252 million years ago high C02 from the Siberian Traps eruptions raised equatorial temperatures to 140 degrees, which caused a mass extinction event. Over 90% of marine animals and 2 out of 3 land animals died out. Ask Happer how we got to 140 degrees if C02 doesn't drive the temperature. I'd love to hear his answer.
author: SwiftlyTiltingPlanet

author: mark boggs

text:
¬†@mark boggs¬† There was a "range" of sensitivity that was settled 20 years ago. The new study simply narrows it down further.

Cosmic rays and significant climate change have no backing in the scientific data, although Svensmark and others have tried. An increase in clouds both cool the planet by reflecting more sunlight and warm it by trapping more heat. So far in the scientific data, it's a wash.  

The sun's heat output as we receive it on earth never varies by more than about a half a degree up or down, even during the grandest of minimums and maximums and over centuries of time. It is remarkably consistent. Therefore the sun has very little influence in CHANGING our climate.
C02, on the other hand, is a much more powerful driver of CHANGE, as it traps increasingly more heat from the sun. This trapped heat concentrates at the poles, which is why average winter temperature in Fairbanks and Anchorage has risen an astonishing 8 degrees F since 1970. Greenland's average temperature is up 7 degrees just since 1991. 

The sun does not and cannot do that. Only a greenhouse effect can do that. 

Milankovitch Cycles, of course, can bring the earth slightly closer to the sun or angle it to receive more direct sunlight over thousands of years, but all three of these cycles are in cooling phases now, not warmng ones. So scratch the sun. 

As our troposphere has continued to warm, the stratosphere just above it has cooled, according to NASA satellite data since 1978. That's pretty clear evidence of heat getting trapped below.
Neither the sun nor any warming driver on earth can simultaneously warm the troposphere while cooling the stratosphere. Only a greenhouse effect can do that. 

I'm not sure if you really absorbed my previous post. Doubling C02 does not double temperature or have double the effect. As I posted, doubling C02 will raise global temperature an average of 3C, which is enough to cause disaster. 

I don't have a bee in my bonnet about Happer, Mark. I've been a science writer since the 1970s, and I've worked with scientists all over the world, have been published in multiple languages in articles and books, and I work with climate data every day. All I'm trying to do here is educate people about Happer's lack of credibility and his erroneous assertions, which are simply unsupported in the scientific literature.

Century after century. It's the accumulation of that "tiny percentage" that's the crux of our problem. Before humans came along, C02 was in balance with the earth's natural filtering system. We've simply upset that balance and exceeded critical mass. 

High C02 in the ancient past was always caused by massive tectonic upheaval, from the break-up of continents. This upheaval would fuel volcanic eruptions for not just days or weeks or months, but for CENTURIES. The Siberian Traps (Google it) is a prime example. 252 million years ago eruptions here continued for thousands of years, spewing trillions of tons of C02 into the atmosphere. That drove equatorial temperatures to 140 degrees, which caused a mass extinction event. Over 90% of all marine animals and 2 out of 3 land animals died out from the heat. 

High C02 like that is NOT NORMAL. Unless, of course, you like 140 degree temperatures and icecaps that inundate part of your country with meltwater.

I have a question on the subject of rising sea levels
  Q: Can the melting glaciers really raise the sea level? 
 I constantly hear this happening almost every time "climate change" "global warming" is mentioned and especially because my 11 y.o. granddaughter (very intelligent for her age. O.k. I admit I'm a little bit biased, just a lil bit) asked me this question.
 Here's the question in her exact words: "Grandma, question..... Will the melting glaciers actually cause the sea levels to rise? I don't really believe this because it makes no sense to me. I asked her if didn't make sense to get and she said...  " Well, because, if I have a glass of ice water and the ice completely melts, my glass does not over flow. Even if I drop ice cubes into a full glass of water, some will spill out, but, only a little even AFTER that ice melts no more water should out. So, how is it possible for the ocean to rise due to global warming and melting glaciers?"
Thank you ahead of time to anyone that answers.
GOD Bless

text: Glaciers are on land so when they melt they can contribute to sea level rise ‚Äî unlike sea ice and icebergs, which would correspond to the ice cubes in your granddaughter's analogy, and do not contribute to the rise of the oceans. However, sea levels have been rising since the mid 1800s when CO2 was relatively low. The world has been warming since the end of the Little Ice Age, which lasted from roughly 1300 to 1850. This warming seems to be the cause of much of the rise of sea level. At one time the River Thames in London used to freeze over for 1 or 2 months at a time. This has not happened since 1814. There weren't many SUVs around at the time so a natural warming seems to have been the cause of the end of the Little Ice Age rather than increased CO2.

text:
People still think that Happer knows anything about climate? He has literally zero training in the field and is part of an extreme political organization that you can't join unless you deny science. The guy's "work" in the field (aka non-peer reviewed opinion pieces) have 100% been debunked and shown to be completely devoid of actual scientific data and conclusions. The sad part is the comments seem to think he actually understands the topic. As a scientist who actually has training in the field, unlike Happer, I weep for the scientific literacy of the US, but perhaps people would be willing to listen to the other side. Don't let Happer's credentials in an unrelated field sway your thinking. I'd be happy to try to explain the topic in more detail for anybody who asks. I'll explain why he gets things wrong as time goes by, but I'll just go through the first 9 or so minutes (although only about 5 or 6 are actually from him):

First, though, one should mention that Happer is not an expert in climate. He has no training in the field. He is essentially illiterate on the topic, and his "works" in the field have been repeatedly debunked and called out for being below even entry level understanding by actual experts. He is also part of an extreme political organization that you can't join unless you deny all science and data regarding climate change.

He first lies and straw mans the topic. Way to go. He misunderstands what a pollutant is by trying to say CO2 can't possibly be one in any form because he literally doesn't even  understand the definition of the word "pollutant." He then calls all scientific data propaganda simply because he doesn't like it.  He then lies and says he knows quite a lot about climate despite him having no training in the field. His training is in optics, which he is a great scientist in, but he does not have training in climate.

He tries to compare scientists who follow the data and are experts in the field with misled crusaders and himself and people with no training or expertise in the field as oppressed truth-seekers been attacked. He says people who support the data and are experts do it for money (despite him getting paid more to spread lies than they get to do actual research), while some do it out of a religious zeal. In other words, he makes up a story, plays the victim card while being the one attacking, straw man's the topic, lies about his opponents, ad hominem's his opponents, and pretends his lack of education gives him magic insight. 

That is the first few minutes. He has provided nothing in defense of his claims or against the science. All he has done is lie and issue baseless ad hominem attacks.

The end of his first 5 minutes lands on his, again, misunderstanding of the term "pollutant." Since he doesn't even understand such a simple term I'll explain it here: a pollutant is anything added to a system that causes unwanted effects. We are adding CO2 to the natural system, and it is causing unwanted effects. Thus, CO2 is, by literal definition, a pollutant with regards to AGW.

Really? I can't believe a person who considers himself an expert and considers experts as people who know nothing would try to use "but humans breathe out CO2" so our GHG emissions are the same thing. The CO2 that living organisms exhale was already part of the biologic sphere, while our emissions of CO2 are, by definition, not. The CO2 that living organisms exhale comes from the natural CO2 in the atmosphere and the food we eat. We are essentially not adding any CO2 to the atmosphere since we are just moving it around. Us pulling up resources that were sequestered beneath the ground and outside of the natural system, however, is adding GHGs to the atmosphere and biosphere.

For instance, fill a tub with water. Now get a teaspoon and scoop some water out. This cup represents the CO2 emissions of living organisms when they breathe. Pour the water back into the tub. Have you added any water to the tub? No. All you did was put back what was already there. Now, take a different gallon jug and fill it with water from a different source. Pour that jug into the tub. Did the water level increase? Yes, because you added a source point that was not already part of the tub, the same as our GHG emissions are adding GHG's to the atmosphere.

He is either willfully spreading disinformation or is completely ignorant of the topic. Take your pick, because either way he shouldn't be talking on the subject.

text:
‚Äã¬†@mark boggs¬† 
No, CO2 is a pollutant no matter which side you are on. Even those who deny climate science can't deny that CO2 is causing the atmosphere to warm. That makes it a pollutant by definition.

I had to write all of that to explain just the simple things he gets wrong in his start. He never even got to the science. He just simply issued false statements about what a pollutant is and analogies and baseless ad hominem attacks on other people. He is the one who keeps not getting to the science in his opening about, ostensibly, the science. If he would actually get to the science I could actually debunk him. Remember, I'm only to the 9 minute mark.

Humans are not outside of the natural system. As I stated previously, we are part of it. However, we are pulling up sequestered point sources for GHG emissions. These sources were buried and not part of the active cycle. In the future they may have been, but they are not currently. That is why we are adding to the current system. Volcanic activity is part of the current system, but volcanic emissions account for roughly 1% of man's emissions.

The graph at 24:10 is simply an absorption/emission spectrum, although upside down from what some might normally see. Essentially, GHG's absorb radiation of specific frequencies. Doubling of CO2 alone would only cause a small increase, but we would actually be quintupling CO2 to get to 800 ppm. Thus the difference would be much larger. However, it isn't just CO2 we look at. We have other GHG emissions, and our emissions are causing feedback loops. Increased temperature allows for more water vapor, which can also increase atmospheric temperature. It also changes the albedo of an area, which is the amount of radiation reflected. A lower albedo allows more energy to be absorbed, and this heats the area. For example, ice has a high albedo but open water and land do not. When the ice melts it allows the area to heat up even more since more radiation can be absorbed, which can cause more ice melt. One should also note that it doesn't take much to see large impacts on the climate.

He then goes on to say that we are trying to take away rights and liberties, that we are being dictators, and the like. He is appealing to emotion and not data.

text:
¬†@Roger Lindahl¬†  Spectroscopic analysis clearly shows heat passing through C02 in the atmosphere and radiating back to earth. That's an empirical fact. It won't change. It also reveals that C02 levels in the atmosphere are increasing. That's an empirical fact. It won't change. 

Isotopic analysis shows that a substantial amount of C02 in the atmosphere came directly from the burning of fossil fuels. That's an empirical fact. It won't change. 

Temperature has risen as our C02 accumulation has risen. Empirical fact. The rise of C02 began around the time of the Industrial Revolution. Empirical fact. The sun's last three cycles progressively weakened, yet we continued to warm anyway. Empirical fact. Earth's orbital eccentricty, axial tilt and precession are all in cooling phases, yet we continue to warm anyway. Empirical fact. 

As our lower atmosphere has warmed, the atmospheric layer just above it has COOLED, according to NASA monitoring since 1978. That's evidence of the heat trapped below and prevented from filtering back into space. Natural cycles can't explain why satellites measure less¬†heat¬†escaping to space at the precise wavelengths which¬†CO2¬†absorbs (Philipona 2004,¬†Wang 2009). 

Neither the sun nor any warming force on earth can simultaneously warm the lower atmosphere while cooling the outer one. Only a greenhouse effect can do that. 

There is much in climate science that is indeed settled. Surely new facts will be added and some information refined but these won't change the empirically-based foundation of truth the new data will rest upon.

text:
We are in the most alarming situation that has ever occurred in human history, but we cannot be alarmists.  "Alarmist" is a bad word, because we call ‚Äúalarmists‚Äù the fools and ignorants that promote Man-Made-Global-Warming.  Universities are a shame, not just the students, who maybe can be easily fooled. PhD professors and PhD researchers claiming that we all shoud go vegans because cow farts produce Global Warming and many other nonsense.  Are they idiots? Even NASA and NOOA are a real huge shame.

BIG ICE AGE
The easiest and simplest, understandable way you can explain the BIG ICE AGE to your family, friends and to everyone you find on your way and that does not require any science background, not even basic science, is the following: 

Man-made-global-warming is nonsense.  CO2 is not a pollutant.  CO2 is food for plants, food for life, food for happiness.  CO2 is really good for every living thing on Earth.

The Sun manages the Earth‚Äôs climate.  The Sun creates the Earth‚Äôs climate.  

As we know, the Sun has a cycle of 11 years on average and as its activity increases, so does the number of spots on its surface.  The action of the Sun reaches the entire Solar System.  It reaches the Earth, which is mainly oceans.  There in the oceans, the Earth‚Äôs climate will finish cooking. 

But the Earth has the Moon, so the action of the Sun that reaches the Earth is modified and modulated by the presence of the Moon.

The Moon has several cycles, of which, for now, we are interested in two of them.
The synodic cycle, from New Moon to New Moon and the metonic cycle. 

This metonic cycle is named after Meton, a very wise guy who lived in Greece 500 years before Christ.  He realized that 235 lunations, i.e., 235 synodic cycles, were equivalent to 19 years, with an accuracy of less than two and a half hours. Very wise Meton.

This means that if on July 16, 2019 there is Full Moon, then in the year 2000 (19 years before), as well as in the year 2038 (19 years later), there is also Full Moon on July 16.

Then we have a solar cycle of 11 years and we have a lunar cycle of 19 years.  If we multiply 11x19, we now have a cycle of 209 years composed of the action of the Sun and the way in which this action is modified and modulated by the presence of the Moon.  
 
At the peak of each eleven year solar cycle, its magnetic poles will exchange places. The north magnetic pole goes to the South and the south magnetic pole goes to the North.  So, the complete solar cycle is actually 22 years.

And, then again: 22x19=418.  Two hundred years ago, the Dalton Minimum occurred and four hundred years ago the Maunder Minimum, the Little Ice Age, occurred.  As they say, we have these two trains arriving at the same time. 

Let's talk a little about History.  We currently use the Gregorian Calendar, a true masterpiece.  It has an error of one day every 3,333 years.  The Mayans had a slightly more precise calendar, an error of one day every 5,000 years.
We all understand the Gregorian Calendar.  Anyone can say how many days will it take for his next birthday or for Christmas.  The Mayan Calendar was understood only by priests.

The Mayans recorded important astronomical, political and social events on stone columns or Stelae and on the upper part of the Stela, they recorded the date of the Long Count in which the event had taken place.  The Long Count was a downward count and would have started 3,114 years before Christ, time in which, according to historians, there were no Mayans. 

A very clever english guy named Thompson, based solely on Stelae that recorded astronomical events, found the correlation between the Long Count and the Gregorian Calendar.  The end of the Long Count indicated the death of the Fifth Sun. 

The Fifth Sun is the one we see every day flying high in the sky.  The Long Count ended on December 21, 2012.

La acci√≥n del Sol llega a todo el Sistema Solar.  Llega a la Tierra, que es principalmente oc√©anos.  Ah√≠ en los oc√©anos, terminar√° de cocinarse el clima de la Tierra.

La Luna tiene varios ciclos, de los cuales, por ahora, estamos interesados ‚Äã‚Äãen dos de ellos.  El ciclo sin√≥dico, de Luna Nueva a Luna Nueva y el ciclo met√≥nico.

Este ciclo met√≥nico se llama as√≠ en honor a Met√≥n, un tipo muy sabio que vivi√≥ en Grecia 500 a√±os antes de Cristo.  Met√≥n se di√≥ cuenta de que 235 lunaciones, es decir, 235 ciclos sin√≥dicos, eran equivalentes a 19 a√±os, con una precisi√≥n de menos de dos horas y media. Bien sabio Met√≥n.

Esto significa que si en Julio 16 de 2019 hay Luna Llena, entonces en el a√±o 2000 (19 a√±os antes), as√≠ como en el a√±o 2038 (19 a√±os despu√©s), tambi√©n hay Luna Llena en Julio 16.

En el punto m√°ximo de cada ciclo solar de once a√±os, los polos magn√©ticos del Sol intercambian lugares. El polo magn√©tico norte se va al Sur y el polo magn√©tico sur se va al Norte.  Entonces, el ciclo completo del Sol es, en realidad, de 22 a√±os.

Y, nuevamente: 22x19=418. Hace doscientos a√±os, ocurri√≥ el M√≠nimo de Dalton y hace cuatrocientos a√±os ocurri√≥ el M√≠nimo de Maunder, la Peque√±a Era de Hielo.  Como dicen, tenemos estos dos trenes que llegan al mismo tiempo.

Hablemos un poco de Historia.  Actualmente usamos el Calendario Gregoriano, una verdadera obra maestra.  Tiene un error de un d√≠a cada 3,333 a√±os.  Los Mayas ten√≠an un calendario un poco m√°s preciso, un error de un d√≠a cada 5,000 a√±os.

La Cuenta Larga era una cuenta descendente y habr√≠a comenzado 3,114 a√±os antes de Cristo, tiempo en el cual, seg√∫n los historiadores, no hab√≠a Mayas.

a la naturaleza rudimentaria de sus m√©todos, es muy dif√≠cil que pudieran alcanzar el conocimiento de la Cuenta Larga con total precisi√≥n.  Creo que este es un conocimiento mucho m√°s antiguo que los Mayas recibieron y preservaron.

De todos los Grandes M√≠nimos Solares que han ocurrido en los √∫ltimos milenios, ninguno es comparable al actual.  Este ser√° mucho peor y mucho m√°s largo. Durar√° cientos de a√±os. Tal vez, miles de a√±os.

text: It may not be that simple.  The jury is still out on whether anthropogenic warming would have the same or a lesser effect as natural Milankovitch Cycles. Because of the natural progression of earth's wobble, the Northern Hemisphere had a 7% increase in solar radiation during the Green Sahara compared with now. (Berger, 1988; Kutzbach, 1981) The main climatic effect of precession (wobble) is to shift the season when the Earth has its closest pass to the Sun (perihelion) ‚Äî the so-called precession of the equinoxes. Today, perihelion occurs in northern hemisphere winter but at 10,000 years ago (half of a precession cycle) it occurred in northern hemisphere summer. That increase could have escalated African monsoonal rainfall by 17% to 50%, according to a 1997 study published in the journal Science.

author: TL Winslow

text:
¬†@TL Winslow¬† Yet, Mr. Winslow, spectroscopic analysis shows an INCREASING amount of heat 
re-radiating back from C02 molecules. As the troposphere continues to warm, the stratosphere above it has actually COOLED, according to NASA satellite monitoring since 1978. That's evidence of less heat escaping from below. Natural cycles can't explain why we measure less¬†heat¬†escaping to space at the precise wavelengths which¬†CO2¬†absorbs (Philipona 2004,¬†Wang 2009).

Neither the sun nor any natural warming driver on earth can simltaneously warm the troposphere while cooling the stratosphere. Only a greenhouse effect can do that. And this greenhouse effect is growing.

It's growing from our C02 emissions and warming's feedback effects of increased water vapor and methane, both powerful greenhouse gases in themselves, along with reductions in sun-reflecting ice albedo, which all work together synergistically to increase warming well beyond what C02 could do alone.

text:
Solar panels and batteries are improving at a steady rate. Batteries are approaching a point where they can last for very long periods of time. Solar panels, if integrated into the sunny walls and roofing of every home and building, could easily replace much of the grid as we know it,  The grid could be eliminated entirely in many places. 
Solar panels can run factories with large power demand and solar panels charge in cloudy weather quite well. I have relied on solar energy for over a decade, and my system is only average in size. Solar panels are absolutely amazing. My solar setup has been very reliable, and I have never had to use a generator since my system was installed. Of course, big power will say otherwise. 
In places where the sun does not shine, wind power is also useful. The technology is also steadily advancing, and new concepts are being tried everywhere. Both solar and wind power have their place, and probably, solar panels will one day be considered the most amazing device ever discovered. 
In time, the solar panel will improve and become ever more efficient and durable, and both solar panels and batteries will  be made to be recyclable. A very promising place for installation of solar cells are road surfaces. This energy is close to where it is needed for charging electric vehicles.

text:
¬†@John Wise¬† NASA Earth fact sheet supports the ISA.

NASA did change the blackbody temperature but not the surface. I've been looking at temperatures from 1980 compared to last year and little difference on most of them. 

Some places with hundred year data hardly any change (in more rural areas) others in major cities around a degree. A change in surface temperature is not global and anything above 3000 Meters (that's not at the tropics where the main bulk of solar irradiation strikes) is freezing.

The average global temperature is consistent with the Earth's average exhaust temperature.

CO2 contribution would be more in molar mass increase than anything else.

text:
I got about 10 minutes in before  Happer lied about the CO2 we breathe out and that emitted by a coal plant. 



The CO2 we exhale IS DIFFERENT from the CO2 coming out of a coal plant.  Carbon isotope analysis of the ratios of C12, C13 and C14 attributes the 46% increase in atmospheric CO2 to the burning of fossil fuels



Human beings do exhale almost three billion tons of carbon dioxide annually, but the carbon we exhale is the same carbon that was ‚Äúinhaled‚Äù from the atmosphere by the plants we consume. (When we eat meat, we're still eating the same carbon, except that it passes through livestock on its way into our mouths and out into the atmosphere.) The only way to add to the carbon in the atmosphere is to take it from a sequestered source like fossil fuels‚Äîwhere it has been safe from the atmosphere for millions of years‚Äîand combust it. So breathe easy..

text:
Mars average temp is -62C.  Scientists attribute 9C of that to the 
greenhouse effect.  So without 1500% CO2 of what Earth has, Mars would 
have an average temp of -71C.  I know it's not that easy, but just for 
"ballparking" where Mars would be with the same solar radiance as Earth,
 assume a linear rise in average temperature by increasing the solar 
radiance by a factor of 2.25, resulting in the greenhouse contribution 
of temperature increase to about 22C.  This gives Mars an average temp 
of about -40C with the same solar radiance as Earth and 1500% CO2 
compared to Earth. Again this is only a "ballpark" number.  Earth's 
average temp is about 15C with .04% CO2. Now suppose we add 78% N2 and 
21% O2 to the Mars atmosphere  making Mars like Earth.  This would not 
cause warming of Mars because N2 and O2 are transparent to the solar 
radiance and do not trap heat. So even with an atmosphere and the same 
solar radiance as Earth, Mars would still be extremely cold and all that
 CO2 would not make a difference.

text: We can‚Äôt control volcanic eruptions and solar activity.  Two major factors which scientifically without doubt most significantly can affect climate cycles, humidity in the atmosphere, temperature, CO2 levels, etc.  There is the science relating to climate.  Man‚Äôs responsibility can only be to act and develop more in harmony with nature.  This means to manage our own population responsibly, not destroy all our forests, keep 50% of land area for natural habitats for other life, stop encouraging land erosion into the sea, stop concreting and asphalting so much of the worlds surface area, limiting toxic pollutants and damaging gases (e.g. methane), etc.  If these measures will affect the climate, we don‚Äôt know and cannot really have any confidence at all about CO2 initiatives alone - because solar / volcanic activity can be far more significant in terms of overall weighting.  Western man-made CO2 theories are to say the least very unproven.  We would, however, need to concentrate more on living and sharing this planet more responsibly and cleanly.  The focus must be to ecologically and environmentally act responsibly - and not to try to artificially pretend that man can control our climate significantly and consistently.

text: From 2:26 to 7:40 (a bunch of unfounded claims that the climate movement is analagous to a crusade). @ 7:42 Happer shows a picture of real air pollution in Shanghai pointing out that it is not CO2, CH4 or N2O that you can see. I find this strange when this strange when the recommended levels of indoor CO2 is to keep it below 1000ppm, when humans are responsible for having lifted CO2 levels on a global scale from about 280ppm to 415ppm. High CO2 concentrations make the room fill stuffy and affect our ability to think according to studies. Why is Mr. Happer then trying to say that CO2 is not a pollutant? @ 9:10 Mr. Happer seems to make a big deal about that we humans contribute CO2 to the atmosphere just by breathing to point that it is not a pollutant because it is natural or because we contribute to its the atmosheres CO2. But this is a warped argument, because he is neglecting the other half of the story which is that our bodies take in carbon when we eat food! Think about it. If we weigh the same all the time, then the net effect is that we always store the same amount of carbon in our bodies. The carbon that enters our bodies has to be balanced with the carbon that leaves our bodies. So our mere existence is not contributing to the buildup of CO2 in the atmosphere! In an airtight room you would eventually die from CO2 poisoning.  @ 10:48 Happer says "We've just seen how well solar farms and wind mills don't work in Texas". The majority of Texas' electricity failures was due to gas pipelines failing because they were no winterized as was recommended to do. They didn't winterize their wind mills or solar farms either. This comment seems unscientific and propogandistic in nature. @11:30 Happer decries subsidies for Wind and Solar power but fails to mention that fossil fuels are subsidized at a much larger level and decries these subsidies as a way to steal from the poor and give to the rich. Strange. @27:49 Mr. Happer shows a graph claiming that it shows that the effects of absorbption of thermal radiation by the atmosphere with a doubling of CO2 would be indistinguishable from not doing it (going from 400ppm to 800ppm). This is misleading because this graph does not account for other effects which explain why a doubling in CO2 causes an increase in absorption of thermal radiation in watts per square meter and hence a warming of about 1 degrees C if feedback effects are not included and about 3.5 degrees C of warming if feedback effects are included; it turns out that the velocity of CO2 can cause a shift in the wavelengths of radiation they aborb (not shown in the graph). If you account for this shift and feedback effects you get the usual relationship between global temperatrue increase and an increase in CO2 concentration in accordance with the equation deltaT=5.35*(ln(C)/ln(C_0), where C_0, C and deltaT are respectively, start concentration of CO2 in the atmpshere, end concentration of CO2 and increase in global average surface temperature. @ 30:30. Ask yourself why Mr. Happer decided to cherry pick the time period 1993-2012 when the oceans happen to be responsible for absorbing large amounts of heat from the atmosphere in order to generate this graph?  Why not look at what happened in 2010-2020? I am out of time. I hope people learn to be critical of their sources.

text:
Let's first look at this from incoming light. The Sun, with an effective temperature of approximately 5800 K, is an approximate black body with an emission spectrum peaked in the central, yellow-green part of the visible spectrum. Of that, about 55% of incoming sunlight to Earth is infrared photons. They strike the Earth and are reradiated back out into the atmosphere. The other 45% is white light and of that, about 30% is reflected which is what you would see if you were to look at the Earth from outer space. That should leave about 31.5% of the total light being white, to strike the Earth and be reradiated in the Earth's black body 255k infrared range back into the atmosphere. That would mean 55% of infrared photons coming in and 86.5% of total infrared photons going out. As we increase secondary greenhouse gases, CO2, CH4, O3, N2O, CFCs, and HCFCs, in the atmosphere, we block more incoming infrared photons, slightly cooling off the planet.   In addition, some incoming white light is converted into kinetic energy (heat), in the atmosphere by the secondary greenhouse gases before reaching the planet.  Being there are more outgoing infrared photons than incoming, we should trap more outgoing infrared photons than reflecting incoming photons. That being said, all things being equal, on the mean, the planet must heat.
https://phys.org/news/2021-01-holocene-temperature-affirms-role-greenhouse.html


Now let us look at this from the secondary greenhouse gas CO2.  One of CO2's properties is it has a reactive band in the 255K range where it absorbs and releases infrared photons in Earth's black body radiation range. Once released after absorption, there is one chance in 41,253 that infrared photon will continue within one degree in the same direction. This basically gives that photon a 50/50 chance of going either up or down. Since the oceans cover about 71% of the Earth's surface, this gives that photon about a 35% chance of hitting a body of water. Infrared photons will not penetrate a body of water's surface, but will instead excite an H2O molecule causing evaporation. H2O is the primary greenhouse gas that prevents the Earth from having a climate like our moon, -18C on the mean. Consequently, the more CO2 we put into the atmosphere, the more H2O gets into the atmosphere, the warmer the planet gets. This is how a 46% increase in CO2 caused a 7% increase in absolute humidity. The present increase in temperature due to this combination of additional H2O and CO2 with over a doubling of CH4, in the atmosphere is approximately 1.2C. Because it takes a tremendous amount of time for the oceans to heat, it will take centuries for the Earth to reach temperature equilibrium. If we continue to inject 37 gigatonnes annually of CO2 into the atmosphere, that heating process will continue to accelerate.

text:
This is not a fair assessment of Apocalypse Never. 

While Shellenberger makes the argument throughout that the earth may be greening and that it is important to let developing counties use fossil fuels for their development, he repeatedly and frequently states, throughout the book, that climate change (and global warming) is happening and that it is a serious concern to the world. 

Shellenberger simply makes the argument that it is important to let lower economy countries develop through the use of fossil fuels. He does not make the argument that global warming is not real and that we should not do anything about it.
author: Jeremiah Cutright

text: ¬†@Jeremiah Cutright¬† if the earth were greening such that a catastrophe were imminent, it seems to me that neither Shellenberger nor any other environmentalist would support any underdeveloped country continuing to use fossil fuels. A reasonable conclusion is that the "apocalypse" is not imminent.
author: Comes a Horseman

text:
¬†@Comes a Horseman¬† It seems to me that the reasoning is because Shellenberger understands that there is a tradeoff between human prosperity and environmental damages. He makes the case for developed countires to reduce their emissions (responsibly, mainly through nuclear and not through solar or wind to which I strongly agree with) while the developing countires can use fossil fuels to simply get out of poverty and then transition to greener fuels. 

The idea behind it is to not trade emission reductions in developed countries with emissions gains in developing countries. Ideally this produces minimal to no acceleration of co2 emissions while simultaneously bringing vast parts of the world out of poverty. 

Once that is achieved, the idea is to responsibly reduce emissions on a global scale. In this scenario there is a potential for warming beyond what could be done under drastic measures that the IPCC likes to being forth, but it is also increasing prosperity so the tradeoff may be worth while. 

Finally, I think most people can agree that fossil fuels (especially coal power plants) are not the best way to produce energy. They cause massive amount of pollutants (this videos assessment of gobi desert dust in Shanghai as air pollution is a red herring, it is irrelevant because it is both that and air pollution, while many places see pollution from fossil fuels on massive scales), are inefficient, and if the costs are averaged over their lifetimes, are extremely expensive. A coal plant, for example, is cheap to build but expensive to operate. This makes it over the course of it's like far more expensive than a comparable nuclear, hydro, or even in some cases wind farms (obviously this varies depending on the site)

Shellenbergers argument is that yes, there is climate extremism, but that climate change is still an issue worth attention. And that we should focus on mitigating this issue as well as reducing poverty around the world and eventually the world can slowly turn to a cleaner world overall.
author: Jeremiah Cutright

text:
¬†@Jeremiah Cutright¬† if by "trade-off" you mean the Green New Deal, no thank you. 
I do agree with Shellenberger about nuclear energy, and I'm relieved that you seem to as well. It will do the world in general no good at all if developed countries bring their economies to a grinding halt in order to tilt at windmills.
author: Comes a Horseman

text:
¬†@Comes a Horseman¬† I cannot say if I favor the green new deal or not because it does not specify any specific solutions. It was, unfortunately, purley a political move. 

However, president Biden has left room open for nuclear power in his climate plan which makes me hopeful he can influence the rest of the left to consider it as an option (although I doubt many Democrats will be willing to consider it). Renewables have their problems, for sure, but they were not responsible for the texas power outages as was incorrectly pointed out in this video. Every type of power production was responsible and natural gas was responsible for more power outages than any other form of energy in that situation. Solar and wind certainly have their place but they are not always applicable. What frustrates me is when it is ignored that they can be useful in certain circumstances. Just like everything, they certainly have their place and can provide a good amount of power for the world (specifically offshore wind because offshore winds are reasonably consistent) but it is important to make sure they are not proliferated beyond where they are applicable.
author: Jeremiah Cutright

text: ¬†@Jeremiah Cutright¬† the mistake made in Texas was using old technology like windmills as part of the grid. They failed first, and that started a cascade. Renewables, which take fossil fuels to construct, are not a large-scale answer.
author: Comes a Horseman

text: ¬†@Comes a Horseman¬† my understanding is that pipes froze at natural gas and nuclear plants in which case whatever power source went down first is irrelevant. Wind can be used at large scale some places and can be more economical in some situations. The nordic countries have proven this extensively and there are many plans for offshore wind in China, the US and europe. Consistent, strong, offshore winds can provide comparable energy reliability to coal and costs similar to nuclear
author: Jeremiah Cutright

text: ¬†@Comes a Horseman¬† also the idea that it takes fossil fuels to construct is a red herring. This is because while yes they do, they can be constructed through being powered by no-carbon solutions once the technology is there, it just happens that it is the beginning stage so the infrastructure is not there yet. There are things such as cement creation and the bessemer process which will be very difficult to overcome, but these can in theory be replaced by forces that simply replace fossil fuels with high voltage electric to create heat. If that electric is created with 0-carbon energy, than the whole process becomes carbon neutral or very near to it.
author: Jeremiah Cutright

text: ¬†@Jeremiah Cutright¬† "it just happens...that the technology is not there yet." Pie in the sky dude; I'll stick with something that's here on the ground working *now*, not maybe-in-the-future.
author: Comes a Horseman

text:
¬†@Comes a Horseman¬† that sort of attitude is simply the wrong to view the world. Of everyone had that attitude about everything, humans would still be living in caves. Even in the case of nuclear today that is the case. Nuclear plants are extremely expensive to build and are becoming increasingly non-competitive. But the onset of next generation nuclear could change that dramatically. Simply put, progress requires hope. And as I stated previously, in some circumstances renewables are already cost competitive. Therefore it is not a "pie in the sky" but simply something that takes time to integrate through society. 

I think if you do more unbiased independent research on the competitiveness of renewables you will find (as I have) that they are not a pie in the sky but are instead now coming out of the oven. 

Keep in mind that like electric cars, wind and solar Technology is not a new idea. It has been attempted before and failed before. But now it is coming into the light because we finally have the technical capacity to make it work. I do not advocate for solar because of the problems it can create, but I still see that it can be useful in certain situations. There never has been and never will be a one size fits all for energy solutions, so it is imperative that we retain all of our assets for use in areas where they are best suited.
author: Jeremiah Cutright

text: ¬†@Jeremiah Cutright¬† and the bottom line really is this, my friend. I've been hearing gloom-and-doom climate predictions since at least 1970, none of which have come to pass. And, I'm getting tired of the constant lecturing and screeching. See the old fable about the boy who cried wolf. Believe what you will, I'm not about to be panicked into giving up fossil fuel technology, which has contributed so much that is good to this world.
author: Comes a Horseman

text:
¬†@Robrecht saski¬† I find this argument not very applicable because of several reasons.

First: while natural forces do contribute to CO2 they also remove them, while human emissions do not. Additionally, volcanoes are frequently pointed to as producing lots of carbon but it has been refuted countless times that no, in fact volcanoes do not emit that much co2. In fact, they have a cooling effect because of the sulfur dioxide they release. 

Second: your estimation of how much co2 is being released by humans in proportion to other natural forces is off. Do you have a source where you got that figure from so that I can check it? 

Third: nobody is arguing that climate change is not part of a natural cycle.  The argument being made is that what is happening now is not natural at all because of the acceleration of co2 concentrations.
author: Jeremiah Cutright

text:
¬†@Comes a Horseman¬† and I respect that position. My final argument is simply this: regardless of if climate change is real or not, fossil fuels are simply an inferior technology to what we have today. 

Nuclear, hydro, geothermal and offshore wind can provide us with all of our energy but are just as reliable as fossil fuels while also not producing nearly as much pollution.

text:
The funny thing is, the Climate Cult advocates for Carbon Tax, regulations and government control... so they can plant carbon offsets (more plants) to "repair the damage done by mankind"... (in other words, "we need to tinker w/ nature b/c people before us tinkered w/ nature")

But higher CO2 concentrations allows plantlife to thrive. Thus creating more plants to process CO2 and other pollutants into breathable Oxygen. Literally achieves the same thing they want to achieve...except it would not give government the control and ability to tax something that's not harmful.

It comes down to 2 major competing ideas. The Cult's beliefs, and those of us who advocate for natural solutions (more plants, more ability to process CO2). They want to limit CO2, when CO2 is what plants need to "breathe". The Climate Cult's idea is akin to saying we should remove Oxygen b/c it might warm the planet slightly

If you get deeper, you find there's no possible way to measure things like a "global average temperature" (something the Climate Cult uses to scare their audience), b/c there's many layers of atmosphere where measurements can be taken... and even if you went to the same exact spots on Earth to measure every day for years... you'd get wildly varying temperature. A "global average" measurement means nothing (except when it's used to scare dumb people who only believe what their favorite media tells them to think)

text: ¬†@peter john kattz¬† Jesus was anything BUT a socialist! Read the story he told about how a man who hired a man to do a job early in the morning. He offered the man a certain amount of money. As the day wore on, he hired more & more - giving them all the same wage. At the end of the day - the last hour, he hired one more person &, according to his promise, he paid him the same wage as all the rest. When the day was over, the man he hired at the beginning of the day complained that the last man hired shouldn't be getting the same amount of wages as he received for working all day whereas the last man hired only worked for an hour. Jesus went on to say the man who hired everyone, told the man, "Did I not agree to pay you a certain wage & you agreed to it?" The man responded by agreeing. The hirer went further to say, "Then what is it to you what I paid anyone else? You agreed to the wage offered & so did the last man hired." In other words, the man who was hired first didn't have to agree with the wage - he didn't have to work for him. That it was his choice. THIS is what Capitalism & the free market is. Someone hires you to do a job & pays you what THEY think you are worth, and YOU have to decide whether or not to do the job for the amount offered. This is the free market! Jesus was ANYTHING but a socialist. He believed in a man working for his fruits. He did NOT believe in forcefully spreading the wealth around. There is a HUGE difference between WILLINGLY giving someone something out of the goodness of your heart because you CHOOSE to, & government breathing down your neck to FORCE you to give someone else something you may not want to give or feel obligated to give. Also, charities diminish greatly, when government FORCES people into submission by making them part with what is theirs to give to others who haven't worked for it. - Susan Burns
