¬†@Robrecht saski¬† Sure there is a lot of dark money out there, but best to try and take a more academic approach to the first malware (theism).

Understanding the origins of religiosity & why it may be more important than ever now.¬†
A bit of an essay and also a rolling doc as new science/research keeps becoming available. The synopsis is that what we call 'religion' today is likely¬†(IMO) remnants of ancient (pre-diluvian) science (astronomy & math) that was used to try and determine where or when the next kicking might befall homo sapiens from the sky. This in the wake of various cosmic impact events¬†during the rather brief current¬†biological age, now thought to have commenced around 300ka.¬†
Principally around the periods 70ka (Sholz's star/Toba eruption) and 12.8ka (Younger Dryas) which resulted in cataclysmic¬†events for whatever megafauna was around at the time and also the brief reversal of the magnetosphere around 42ka where again megafauna was fragged from the sky/atmosphere.
I'll send a follow up about why this understanding could be so important now, but (spoiler alert) it harks¬†to another pending stadial/flood event resulting from a calving of the Greenland Ice Sheet, which will then oscillate with various, already critical Antarctic ice sheets (teleconnections) bringing about another stadial/flood event. Nothing as severe as the meltwater pulses associated with the Younger Dryas period, given the lower baseline of ice to start with, but still enough to warrant the term cataclysmic and possibly game ending given the current complexity & concentration in our present settled living arrangements.¬†---------------------------------------
Why do monotheistic religions (choose any) with their associated language, architecture, symbolism and ceremony, catalogue an intense and ancient interest in observing and recording the dimensions of the earth, moon and sun along with relative celestial movements?
¬†Randall Carlson shows that ancient master builders understood earth's fundamental geodetic parameters on a level not equaled until the advent of modern satellite surveys. The great pyramid of Kheops on the Giza plateau is essentially a scale model of the northern hemisphere of earth at a ratio of 1:43,200. Over 2 seconds of time (1/43,200th part of the diurnal rotation) a point on the equator will travel a distance precisely equal to the perimeter of the great pyramids base as measured with the socle. In a 1/2 second of time, a point on the equator will rotate a distance equal to 1 side of the base of the great pyramid as measured with the socle. Its height when measured with the socle is 1/432,000th part of the earth's polar radius.¬†This geodetic knowledge was passed on through time and cultures and similarly encoded within the Parthenon in Greece. Such traditions are continued into more recent times. Gothic cathedrals are typically built with their cubit dimensions based upon a subdivision of the meridian length at the latitude that the cathedral was built. Many other examples exist across cultures, some going very far back. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R7oyZGW99os&list=LL&index=28&t=32s).¬†Sky - Ground mirroring, i.e. lining up complex architectural structures with celestial objects goes back a long, long way.¬† Moreover, the importance of many of these architectural structures, for example; the Giza pyramids, Machu Picchu, Easter Island, Angkor Wat, Mohenjo-Daro, and many others, in their relationship to the Sun and other celestial objects can be further demonstrated by their alignment along a newly recognized type of Earth orbit that can travel directly above a great circle formed by some of these oldest and most distinctive ancient human constructions on the surface of the Earth¬†https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_HytJn6uaRk&list=LLdBbaEuuXa8HPX0fskUQuEA&index=82¬†Roger G. Gilbertson gives a great lecture on this here, again evidencing how the human DNA profile dropped, precipitously off a cliff from around 13,000 years ago - aligning with the Younger Dryas cosmic event and subsequent cooling. This is clear evidence of sophisticated civilizations with skills in stonework (in many cases beyond those present today), astronomy, language with deeply held religious/spiritual practices involving celestial worship. It also calls into question orthodox timelines for civilizational development when taking into account the precession of the equinoxes over time and the relative change in positions of constellations in the night sky.¬†Here, Graham Hancock asks; Was an advanced civilization lost to history in the global cataclysm that ended the last Ice Age? His research takes us on a series of journeys and encounters with the scientific rebels responsible for the recent extraordinary breakthroughs. In the process, from the Mississippi Valley to the Amazon rainforest, he reveals that ancient ‚ÄòNew World‚Äô cultures share a legacy of advanced scientific knowledge and sophisticated spiritual beliefs with supposedly unconnected ‚ÄòOld World‚Äô cultures.¬†https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GAccZ8eWhXo&list=LLdBbaEuuXa8HPX0fskUQuEA&index=60&t=0s¬†¬†The astronomical math itself needed to create these structures would have taken several generations to develop, monitoring and accurately measuring small movements over long timeframes; 72 years equating to 1 day of the astrological or 'great' year of the precession of the equinoxes, i.e. only degree of movement.¬†So, thousands of years ago the earth's dimensions were surveyed with remarkable accuracy and the data was recorded in giant stone structures along with other key astronomical measurements. The astronomical math used to obtain this geodetic knowledge and understanding relies on patterns of so-called sacred numbers, which are similarly incorporated into the mythology/texts of the various mono-theistic religions and likewise of those going back over 5000+ years.¬†Here's some more examples from Randall Carlson (of which there are reportedly many hundreds):
author: Alex Gullen

text: In ancient Greek, the word truth has numbers (its gematria) 72, 7+2 = 9 Other examples are, Jerusalem = 864 which reduces again to 9, Temple of Immortality =864 again, The Holy Ghost = 1,080 (reduces to 9). Revelation 14:1-4 references 'hundred and forty four thousand' which reduces to 9, Revelation 18;4 references 'come out my people' which = 1,296, which reduces to 9. Revelation 13:18 references 'six hundred threescore and six' which relates to earth's orbital speed around the sun 66,600 mph. See also Zacharia 2:1-2, Revelation 21¬†The gematria (study of the numerical basis of language) of religious texts is based on the same architecture of numbers used in geodetic calculations that used astronomical measurements, not by any co-incidence.¬†Whichever religion, whether it involves for instance central characters like Jesus or his depictions from earlier mythologies, i.e. Mithras, Zeus, Osiris or even Krishna (in that order);- they all derive from and encode ancient astronomy relating to the relative positions and movement of the shapes and names of constellations in the sky, planets, moons and obviously the center of it all - the sun. This is further echoed in language, architecture (with embedded mathematics) dating as early as 12,000+ years ago (Gobekli Tepe), symbolism and ceremony, even down to use of body language - the penitent monk praying echoing 5000+ year old Vedic yoga. These themes even echo in popular culture now via the storytelling medium of film.¬†The word God itself provides a useful example of linguistic and other development around source astronomy. The etymology is old English/Germanic in origin. In Germanic it was Goth, which gives us Gothic architecture, or Gut in Scandinavia, which gives you a gut instinct or to follow your gut, i.e. a divine instinct or wisdom. Or back further still, it is Dog (God backwards) because if you go back to Ancient Greece, it stems from the importance assigned to the Sirius Star within the Canis Major system, known as the Dog-Star, i.e. the brightest star in the night sky. Back even further and it gives rise to the most powerful ancient Egyptian deity, Osiris (derivative of Sirius) who ruled over the celestial afterlife the Duat. Sirius leading to the word 'Sir', i.e. someone you typically salute or look up to.¬†There are many other examples to choose from across our shared history of storytelling and encoding hidden meaning. The word 'Church' is an English one coming from the Scottish word, 'Kirk' or 'Kirke' in Scandinavia, which in turn goes back to 'Cerse' in ancient Roman language (a Goddess), itself derived from 'Circe' in ancient Greek mythology. Circe, a goddess and daughter of Helios (also known as Ra or the Sun God in ancient Egyptian mythology), was able to hypnotize humans with wands, potions and herbs, bring them into her home and turn them into animals if offended by them (sometimes eat them for sustenance).¬†Likewise, the Moses tale was originally that of an Egyptian hero, Ra-Harakhti, the reborn sun god of Canopus, whose life story was copied by biblical scholars into the 10 commandments, plagiarized from the Egyptian story of negative confessions out of the Egyptian Book of the Dead. Tibet has one of those too. The acts performed by Moses with the flowering rod, river of blood, and tablets of the law were also symbols derived (plagiarized) from Greek mythology. For instance, the miracle of drawing water from a rock was first performed by Mother Rhea (sister and wife of Cronus) after she gave birth to Zeus, and by Atalanta with the help of Artemis. The miracle of drying up the waters to travel dry-shod was earlier performed by Isis, or Hathor, on her way to Byblos. Different versions can be found originating out of India.¬†Jesus (whichever version you prefer) is also a symbolic metaphor for spiritual and intellectual enlightenment, not an actual person as it is commonly portrayed today. Dr Richard Carrier, one of the few who has conducted academic research into the historicity of the Jesus character is a good place to look. The triangle or holy trinity of father, son and holy ghost similarly echoes throughout belief systems over time. The fable of turning water into wine is an exercise in science from the Egyptians who understood that it was sun, plus water (rain) and time that gave life to the vines producing grapes, giving rise to wine (yes the Egyptian's had the earliest wines). You are unwittingly learning about the processes of photosynthesis and transpiration over time responsible for plant growth.¬†The word Israel is another representation of past themes. Isis was the Egyptian moon goddess (In Egyptian mythology, Isis was an Egyptian mother goddess; wife-sister of Osiris, sister of Nephthys, mother of Horus, noted for having played a key role in the resurrection of the dead Osiris (sound familiar), after his hacking into 14 pieces by the god Set, as told in the famous story "Passion of Osiris" (later re-branded to the Passion of Christ). Ra was the sun god of Egypt. Saturn was the god of the Elohim. Isis (Is), Ra, and Elohim (El) = IsRaEl.¬† This is also where words like elected, elevated and elite derive from.¬†Horus was thought of as the "height of the heavens" and ranked as the oldest god of Egypt, who became re-conceptualized in the Dynastic era, via the Heliopolis recension (circa 2,500BC), as the son of Osiris (Sirius/Dog Star) and Isis (Ra/Sun). Horus leads to the word horizon. When Jesus, son of God walked on water, this is actually symbolic of light dancing across water (likely the Nile) as the sun sets - maybe they also saw green flashes as the sun dipped out of sight and became aware of the significance of 42 degrees, at they seemed to have a real thing for embedding the mathematics of complex astronomy within the physical dimensions of the ancient Egyptian stone structures (Ghiza pyramid for example:¬†https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R7oyZGW99os&list=LL&index=28&t=32s) Here is a good explanation of the importance of 42 degrees and how a sphere (the sun?) can act as a prism and break up light according to its various wavelengths¬†https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yEGRjSGrPnU¬†.¬†The importance of the Sun is reflected in common usage symbology - Christian and Judeo crosses typically have a circle around the intersection. This represents the sun and the 4x points on the zodiac (N, E, S & W). This is why there are 4x Gospels, 1 for each season (Spring, Summer, Autumn and Winter), however there is only 1x original Gospel, that of Luke from which all other stories/gospels were spun. Luke comes from Luca. Luca derives from "lux" which means "light" in Latin. Luca (and Luke) means "light", having the same root as Lucy, Lucius in Roman times. In fact, in the ancient times, Luca was the name given to babies born at dawn, since dawn is the first light (lux) of the day.¬†The Age of Aquarius is an astrological age (a month), which occurs because of a real motion of Earth known as the precession of the equinoxes that causes the identity of the Pole Star to change over time. The cycle of precession, 1 great year lasts 25,920 years, and there are 12 constellations of the Zodiac (astrological months). So, roughly every 2,160 years, the sun‚Äôs position at the time of the March, or vernal, equinox moves in front of a new zodiac constellation. The Age of Aquarius (New Testament, Luke 22:10) begins when the March equinox point moves out of the constellation Pisces and into the constellation Aquarius. This transition was marked at the end of 2020 by a rare conjunction of Saturn and Jupiter, not seen for some 800 years. In John 1: 29 John the Baptist which equates to the constellation Aquarius (a man bearing a pitcher of water) refers to the lamb of God, referring to the Aries constellation. Matthew 3: 11-12 referring to a widowing fan for wheat depicted as being held in the hand of the Orion constellation. This recording of celestial 'scenes' in mythological texts goes back over 5,000 years, where instead of Jesus it was Krishna playing a central role. These are just some of the many dozens of examples where stories and characters are direct references to celestial scenes. David Mathisen who has written and lectured widely on the topic is also worth a look. Good explanation here too https://www.nationalgeographic.com/history/article/how-ancient-astronomy-mixed-science-with-mythology
author: Alex Gullen

text:
Saturnists for instance, believe that it is the planet Saturn that is the most powerful deity or God (father of the Sun), which drives the universe. In ancient Rome, Saturn was a God conflated with the Titan, Cronus from prior Greek mythology. Cronus (the father of time), who ruled the Golden Age and took his sister Rheas his incestuous partner. Gaea and Uranus however had prophesied he would be dethroned by one of his offspring. As such, their first 5x offspring together were eaten by Cronus until Rhea managed to switch out the 6th (Zeus) with a stone so he escaped this fate. Modern Christmas festivities derive from the highly popular Roman festival of Saturnalia, a carnival where social norms were reversed and slaves were free for the day and would be served on by their masters.¬†An occultation in Astronomy happens when something becomes hidden behind something else. The last occultation of Saturn was April 25th 2019 when it passed behind or was masked by the moon. Astro-Theology and its meanings are hidden behind and under the surface of modern monotheistic religions, hence the association with the 'occult' and use of masks;- ¬†Kubrick's, Eyes Wide Shut is an interesting reference point in popular culture. ¬†¬†Saturn is considered the King of the Planets within our solar system and like the Dog Star, is one of the brightest objects in the night sky visible to the naked eye. It is also one of the largest and would contain some 750 Earths within it, yet it would float on water due to its low density. It has a large number of satellites, some 53 named (typically after Titans in ancient Greek mythology), Janus, Rhea, Titan (the largest of its moons), Pandora & Prometheus (shepherd moons steadying its rings, which add to its reflectivity and thus brightness in the night sky), Pan are some of the more commonly known examples.¬†One moon, Mimas, was the inspiration for the Death Star in Star Wars. The likeness is unmistakable. The name Luke Skywalker means Sun travelling across the sky in 12 steps (hours). The 'Force' for instance is representative of the influence of Saturn over space and time. Pandora, one of Saturn's many moons, is often referred to with some deeper meaning because it is associated with a box, i.e. a black cube. But this is a misnomer, it was a vase or jar not a box which was left with only hope inside after Pandora (the first woman created by the Gods out of clay in Greek mythology) had opened it.¬†So why is it that the brightest star in the night sky and likely inspiration for the original concept of deity was named the ‚ÄòDog Star‚Äô?¬†Well, it could be reconciled as looking like a simple stick dog when joining the dots and humans do tend to project or look for images of things already in existence in the natural world (animals in the sky), particularly animals of significant meaning or value. The constellation was initially viewed by Mesopotamians and Babylonians as an arrow and bow aiming at Orion. The Ancient Greeks later changed this to a dog. The Canis Major representing the dog Laelap, a gift from Zeus to Europa, or one of Orion's hunting dogs. In medieval Arab astronomy it became 'the greater dog'. Hunting with the bow and domesticated dogs is perhaps one of the longest standing human activities associated with feeding oneself and the tribe or community and is still relevant being practiced in many parts of the world today. Similarly, Graham clearly shows that when dating ancient sites, for instance Giza by its astrological alignment with the Leo and Orion constellations and the river Nile lining up with the Milkyway (thought to then have been the pathway to the afterlife or Duat) and calculating for precession, it dates back in excess of 12,000 years.
So what could have been so important for ancient civilizations around the globe to have undertaken such painstaking science and mathematics and then encode such data into multiple modalities of recorded information (symbology, gematria, language, architecture etc.)? Encodings so ubiquitous as to have made it through time into the mythological texts of today's modern, mono-theistic religions the world over.¬†Astrophysicists recently unearthed deep cycles wherein periodic comet showers occur in the Solar System every 26 to 30 million years, producing cyclical impacts and resulting in periodic mass extinctions. Our solar system cycles through the crowded mid-plane of the Milky Way Galaxy about every 30 million years. During those times, comet showers are possible, leading to large impacts on the Earth. The impacts can create conditions that would stress and potentially kill off land and marine life, including widespread dark and cold, wildfires, acid rain, and ozone depletion. "These new findings of coinciding, sudden mass extinctions on land and in the oceans, and of the common 26- to 27-million-year cycle, lend credence to the idea of periodic global catastrophic events as the triggers for the extinctions,‚Äù said the lead author Rampino. ‚ÄúIn fact, three of the mass annihilations of species on land and in the sea are already known to have occurred at the same times as the three largest impacts of the last 250 million years, each capable of causing a global disaster and resulting mass extinctions.‚Äù We are now in what is now commonly understood to be the 6th mass extinction, although not one resulting from a cosmic event, but through our own self undoing.¬†As for our relatively short 200,000 ‚Äì 300,000 year biological near history, this has not been easy either. For instance, the Younger Dryas cosmic event over 12,000 years ago wasn't likely the first time mega fauna (including early homo sapiens) were nearly wiped out from fireballs raining down from the sky. Around 70,000 years ago, a super volcano named Toba erupted, blowing roughly 670 cubic miles (2,800 cubic kilometers) of vaporized rock and debris into the air. This is thought to have caused a massive struggle for humanity, ultimately leading to a population bottleneck that whittled down our numbers to as few as 1,000 reproductive adults. Notably, this coincided with a nomadic star (Scholz's star) that came within a light-year of the Sun, likely sending dozens of comets and asteroids tumbling out of the solar system from behind the Gemini constellation towards Earth.¬†More recently, the end of the last ice age was an extremely difficult epoch for all megafauna struggling to eke out a life in system Earth. A world whose sky had shattered the ground, blasting through ice and rock with comet impacts changing and mostly wiping out the future of much of life on then Earth and bringing about a subsequent cooling event (Younger Dryas cold episode circa 12,900 to 11,700 years ago) that caused much of the life that had survived the initial events to subsequently fade away. This likely resulted from our planet's close relationship with the Taurid‚Äôs debris belt, which is believed to be the remnants of a much larger comet that disintegrated some 20,000 to 30,000 years ago and has a cycle of activity with a 2,500 - 3000 year frequency. Named Taurids on account of the Taurus constellation from which this activity emanates. Most of the time we pass through this debris belt unscathed, thanks mostly to the dense gravitational pulls of the gas giants Jupiter and Saturn, but we regularly run the gauntlet as we continue to pass through the tail end.¬†The Younger Dryas cosmic event has been corroborated from multiple disciplines of research now across peer reviewed scientific journals. This was an extremely difficult epoch for all megafauna struggling to eke out a life in system Earth. A world whose sky had shattered the ground, blasting through ice and rock, causing huge floods and precipitation events with comet impacts changing and mostly wiping out the future of much of life on then Earth and bringing about a subsequent cooling event (Younger Dryas cold episode circa 12,900 to 11,700 years ago) that caused much of the life that had survived the initial events to subsequently fade away. Here are some of the more recent examples:Rapid range shifts and megafaunal extinctions associated with late Pleistocene climate change, 02 June 2020:¬†https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-020-16502-3¬†Evidence of Cosmic Impact at Abu Hureyra, Syria at the Younger Dryas Onset (~12.8 ka): High-temperature melting at >2200 ¬∞C 06 March 2020:¬†https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-60867-w¬†The wide range of evidence supports the hypothesis that a cosmic event occurred at Abu Hureyra ~12,800 years ago, coeval with impacts that deposited high temperature meltglass, melted microspherules, and/or platinum at other YDB sites on four continents. Published March 2020 in Nature.https://search.proquest.com/openview/0910b81f552b3df68c04ca78699cd9b1/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=2041939¬†A multi-proxy study of changing environmental conditions in a Younger Dryas sequence in southwestern Manitoba, Canada, and evidence for an extraterrestrial event 22 October 2019:https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/quaternary-research/article/multiproxy-study-of-changing-environmental-conditions-in-a-younger-dryas-sequence-in-southwestern-manitoba-canada-and-evidence-for-an-extraterrestrial-event/258145EFAF7D36B9C6AAE8BD16EAEC08¬†Evidence from Pilauco, Chile Suggests a Catastrophic Cosmic Impact Occurred Near the Site¬†‚àº12,800 Years Ago, 27 July 2019:¬†https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-030-23918-3_15

text:
¬†@Plom De Nume¬† I thank you for taking this conversation honestly. I haven't provided many links because of not wanting to take the chance at being blocked.

The lower atmosphere would be about 0 Fahrenheit on average without GHGs in the atmosphere. This is in contrast to the roughly 15 or so degrees Celsius we currently see. 

GHGs are interesting in the way to interact with radiation. Solar radiation is SWR, or short wave radiation. It is a very high frequency, and GHGs don't interact with this radiation. As a body cools from being warmed it emits a longer wavelength radiation back, and we call the radiation the earth sends back to space LWR (long wave radiation). GHGs can interact with LWR, and it absorbs some of this energy and then releases it back into the atmosphere. Some of this goes to space as it would without GHGs present, but some is directed back to earth. This keeps some of that energy from escaping to space and slows the rate of emissions. We have tracked it, actually, by observing the LWR budget in specific electromagnetic bands going to space and going down to earth.

Without GHGs, this LWR would essentially have nothing stopping it from escaping to space, and the earth would cool much faster and cool to a lower temperature at night. It would also not warm as much during the day. It wouldn't lose all heat at night due to the rate of loss and the time before the sun comes back up.

The temperature of ~0 Fahrenheit is what the average would be across the globe without GHGs present, and thus with LWR being able to escape more freely. The earth would still maintain an average above absolute zero because of the warmth during the day and the fact that a radiative body can only radiate so much energy per unit time. This average for the earth has been estimated to be about 0 Fahrenheit.

GHGs increase this by slowing the rate of heat loss, especially at night. This causes the average temperature to be higher throughout the day. It also heats the poles faster than lower latitudes, which causes the average globally to go up more.

I see where you are coming from with the temperature not going beyond what it was, but the actual temperature of the earth during daytime is higher than 15 Celsius. Since GHGs slow the emission back to space the average only drops to about 15 instead of dropping to 0 Fahrenheit. The actual temperature the globe gets to during the day is more than 15 Celsius so GHGs aren't increasing the actual temperature, merely slowing how fast it decreases. The total energy from the sun is more than the energy retained through GHG interactions.

I hope that makes sense.
author: Erik Davis

author: Erik Davis

text:
¬†@Plom De Nume¬† To use your analogy, heat a pot to 40 C and then take the lid off. The pot will cool rapidly. If, however, you put a thin layer of glass over it, the pot will cool more slowly. The total energy of the system remains the same of 40 C in, but the rate of loss slows.

Now, every 20 minutes heat the pot back up to 40 C and then let it drop again. If you take the average temperature in both scenarios, the one with the glass top will have a higher temperature on average even though both still only top out at 40 C.

That is similar to how GHGs work. They don't increase the total energy in the system, but they do cause the average to increase by slowing the rate of loss.

author: CD Marshall

text:
¬†@Plom De Nume¬† We do talk about conduction and convection, it is just that we aren't really altering the other variables nearly as much as we are GHGs. Essentially, other natural forcings are reacting to our emissions, but our emissions are causing a net positive influence on temperature once everything else is taken into account.

The "small" amount of CO2 is also a bit of a misnomer. It is "small" relative to total amount, but it is large relative to the amount we had 150 years ago, and GHGs don't need to see a large increase per million to start causing feedback loops and having direct effects on temperature. 

Now, this is not to say we completely understand all aspects of climate. We don't fully understand everything, which is why we have error bars on our predictions and why study is ongoing (we don't know everything about any topic in science, to be honest). However, the data and evidence we have supports to AGW conclusion. That is how science works in any field. We simply follow the evidence. If somehow something were to come out tomorrow that completely turns the entire science around, explains everything better, could be replicated, and could be demonstrated, we would have no issue accepting it instead. it would have to be supported by a massive a mount of evidence, however.
author: Erik Davis

text:
¬†@Erik Davis¬† so Climate Science is saying an increase of 100ppm CO2 (round figures) has caused a 1 degree increase in temp.  100ppm equates to 1 part per 10,000 parts of non radiative molecules (leaving water aside for the moment). That means each CO2 molecule would have to collide with 9,999 other molecules and transfer 1 degree to each. Which means each CO2 molecule would have to start with a temp of 10,000 degrees! Obviously they can‚Äôt be saying that because that would be stupidity.

But going back to my boiling pot analogy. 150 years ago my pot cooled from 40C down to say 20C overnight. Add today‚Äôs extra CO2 and it only cools to say 25C. Tomorrow when I add the same amount of power to the pot it is still only going to heat to 40C! You can‚Äôt add the extra 5 degrees and make 45C...as in you can‚Äôt make a hot object hotter by adding a cooler object. ( that‚Äôs thermodynamic law)
author: Plom De Nume

text:
¬†@Plom De Nume¬† While there has "only" been an increase of ~120-140 ppm, that equates to an ~50% increase in emissions. You also have to factor in all the other GHGs we emit, water vapor (you can't leave that aside in any way), and feedback loops. Those all bolster the impact, and water vapor concentration and feedback loops are directly influenced by increasing CO2 emissions.

You are also misunderstanding how CO2 increases temperature. It isn't through kinetic energy transfer. I realize you are simply rehashing what the previous two people have tried to say, but it is still a misunderstanding. CO2 increases temperature via reducing LWR emissions to space, not by transferring kinetic energy to surrounding molecules. 

As to your analogy, what is the average temperature after you add CO2? You go from an average of ~30 to an average of ~32.5 degrees. You can also get a slightly higher max temperature due to this excess energy that doesn't get released overnight. The earth does not heat up to the maximum temperature it possibly can from solar radiation each day since it also emits radiation back. This allows you to actually increase the maximum temperature (to, say, 41-45) of the pot (earth) without adding extra energy since it still had energy from the previous day/heating. 

The laws of thermodynamics are not altered or broken in any way.
author: Erik Davis

text:
¬†@Erik Davis¬† no, you cannot get higher temperatures because of a ‚Äòresidual‚Äô thermal energy remaining. You are confusing thermal energy with heat...two entirely different things. Heat only occurs at the point of frequency transfer, it‚Äôs not stored. Heat is a verb not a noun. And heat only ever goes one way....from hot to cold. So you could have any amount of ‚Äòresidual‚Äô thermal energy but it won‚Äôt add heat to a higher thermal energy. 
I think this is also why you keep talking about averages. Yes Climate is the long term average of weather, but the weather is not driven by the climate average but by real time effects of actual phenomena. The sun is hot enough to suck thousands of tons of water thousands of feet into the air creating clouds, rain, Hadley cells, trade winds etc etc. nothing to do with CO2. Combine that with a cooler CO2 not being able to add heat by residual to a hotter temperature, I don‚Äôt get how the science arrives at the hypothesis that it does. Slowing down the cooling does not make it hotter. And slowing down is debatable anyway because the other 9,999 air particles are convecting heat away which is a far greater effect than a minuscule 1 particle slowing it up.
I don‚Äôt mean to be difficult but whole thing just doesn‚Äôt add up for me. And when NOAA admits that their temp data is ‚Äòhomogenised‚Äô then that is an enormous red flag for me. Combine dodgey temp readings with dodgey physics and I‚Äôm leaning towards the sceptic side.
author: Plom De Nume

text:
¬†@Plom De Nume¬† No, you can get higher temperatures in the atmosphere. Yes, heat is the transfer of energy. You are confusing colloquial terms for the scientific terms. That is why I keep trying to use temperature and energy when I can so you and others won't get stuck in semantics instead of looking at the actual argument. 

As I stated before, the total energy received by earth is more than the actual temperature outside would reflect due to the earth continually releasing radiation to space(and being used in other forms). Thus, CO2 can cause the temperature to slowly increase toward that maximum temperature by elevating the average LWR and energy available in the atmosphere instead of letting it escape as rapidly so space.

Again, the energy from the sun is where most all energy for the planet comes from; nobody argues that. However, the solar energy has been decreasing over the years while we continue to increase in global average temperature. This is due to increased GHG emissions for the most part. Remember, while the sun does provide energy to the planet, it is heating the earth from the CMB + internal sources to about 255 degrees Kelvin, with GHG's making up much of the rest above that.

You seem to be misunderstanding how CO2 increases atmospheric temperature. CO2 radiates energy in, roughly, a sphere. Part of the energy goes to space, while the rest gets redirected to earth. If you lower the rate of energy loss of a system, the average energy available to that system per unit time will increase. 

And again, CO2 isn't making the entire system hotter than it would be from solar and internal sources. It simply allows the system to rest at a higher equilibrium state that is still lower than the total energy received from the sun and internal sources. It isn't adding extra energy to the sun, but you don't have to to see an increase in average temperature. Now, if the earth absorbed all radiation from the sun in all forms and didn't emit radiation back, GHGs wouldn't heat the earth since that would adding energy to the system. The earth doesn't behave that way, though.

Convection does play a role, but it doesn't negate the effect of GHGs.

We don't combine dodgy temperature readings and physics. Actually study up on how the data was used, look across departments and fields across the entire globe and across the innumerable scientific fields that confirm AGW. Research the peer review to understand the topic more.

I will freely admit I'm not an expert compared to actual experts, although I do understand far more than the average person. I would recommend studying the literature from publishing experts in the field to learn more.

text:
¬†@Erik Davis¬† 
A BRIEF LESSON IN THERMODYNAMICS
 Heat is a product of hot to cold on a macro or micro level.


All laws must be considered in the concept of the Laws of Thermodynamics.



1st Law of Thermodynamics



The First Law of Thermodynamics simply states that energy can be neither created nor destroyed (conservation of energy). Thus power generation processes and energy sources actually involve conversion of energy from one form to another, rather than creation of energy from nothing.

The change in eternal energy of a system is equal to the heat added to the system minus the work done by the system.



Delta U=Q-W (work done by the system)
Delta U=Q+W (work done on a system)



2nd Law of Thermodynamics


Entropy and Disorder:
100% energy cannot be transformed to work.


Entropy can be produced but never destroyed.



Kelvin & Planck
‚ÄúNo (heat) engine whose working fluid undergoes a cycle can absorb heat from a single reservoir, deliver an equivalent amount of work, and deliver no other effect‚Äù



Clausius
‚ÄúNo machine whose working fluid undergoes a cycle can absorb heat from one system, reject heat to another system and produce no other effect‚Äù


Both statements of the Second Law constrain the First Law of Thermodynamics by identifying that energy goes downhill.

The Second Law is concerned with Entropy (S) which is produced by all processes and associated with the loss of ability to do work. 

The Second Law states that the entropy of the universe increases.



For energy to be available there must be a region with high energy level and a region with low energy level. 

*Useful work must be derived from the energy that flows from the high level to the low level.*



Delta S=Q/T

Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics

If two systems are at the same time in thermal equilibrium with a third system, they are in thermal equilibrium with each other.


Energy, Temperature and Heat are NOT the same thing. Heat is a form of energy in transit, all heat is energy but not all energy is heat. Any system can change energy without a change in temperature. (That longer wave radiation can‚Äôt increase the emissions of shorter wave radiation concept).



CO2 is not adding new energy to the system it is radiating or reflecting energy already in the system.
author: CD Marshall

text:
A brief lesson in atmospheric quantum mechanics

Bosons
Photon Energy=Delta E =hf
 E=Energy of the photon 
h=Plank‚Äôs constant (6.63x10^-34 Js) 
f=frequency of the EM radiation
E = hv C= Œªv. 

E is the energy of the light in Joules (J), h is a constant which is 6.626 X 10-34 J‚Ä¢s, and. v is the frequency of the light in s-1 or waves/s (also called Hertz (Hz). C is the speed of light.

Photons:
 Radiation is quantized into photons whose energy is proportional to frequency: E=hv.

You see low level energy bosons can stack indefinitely without increasing temperature. Photons are particles with frequency-dependent energy and anything re-directed by CO2 are line spectrum not a source; therefore they cannot increase temperature anything above its radiating frequency (naturally when the energy is transferred to a compatible object). 

Photons being bosons as such means at low temperatures they behave differently than fermions because an unlimited number of bosons can collect into the same energy state,(The Bose-Einstein Distribution).  

* That means energy can increase without raising the temperature*

#1 The action of photons impacting a surface does not imply the photons will be absorbed. ‚ÄúAbsorption‚Äù is only one of several things that can happen to a photon. It all depends on wavelengths. A very short wavelength, relative to the surface, will actually penetrate the surface‚Äîthink X-rays. A very long wavelength, relative to the surface, will be reflected. Absorption depends on a close compatibility between the photon‚Äôs wavelength and that of the surface.  

#2 Atmospheric CO2 absorbs mainly at a wavelength of 15 microns. That corresponds to energy of 0.0827 eV. To put that into perspective, it would take about 77,760,000,000,000,000,000,000 {7.776 x10^22} such photons to transfer energy to equal 1 Joule. So it would take 4.2 times that many photons worth of energy transference to raise 1 gram of water 1 degree Celsius which would never happen with 15 microns emitted by CO2 because it cannot radiate above its spectrum frequency when absorbed and transferring that energy  as I have stated [line spectrum not source]. 

Longer wave/frequency radiation DOES not increase the temperature of shorter wave/frequency radiation

Wien‚Äôs Displacement Law: (Lower case) Lambda {Œª} Max= b {Wien‚Äôs Displacement Constant} / T {absolute temperature of a blackbody} 15 micrometers (micron) emits energy in transference (0.0827 eV) equal to a blackbody emitting at 193.2 Kelvin (-79.97 Celsius). 

Something colder than ice cubes will not raise the average ambient temperature of the Earth EVER.  

 >1 Joule = 6.24x10^18 eV Or, 1 Joule = 6,240,000,000,000,000,000 eV   

>One MeV is one megaelectron volts or one million electron volts, and the MeV is a measure of energy. It is equal to 1.60217646 √ó 10^-13 joules.  

An ice cube emits mainly at a wavelength of 10.7 microns. So the energy of ice photons are about 50% ‚Äúhotter‚Äù than photons emitted/reflected by CO2.  

#3 If a photon is reflected then there is no energy exchange, reflection happens as often as absorption, otherwise our eyes would be of little use. Unless you are looking into a source, such as a fire or the sun, you are able to see because of reflected photons.   

For vibration and/or rotational modes, there must exist a magnetic dipole for photon absorption to occur. The molecule is unaffected by nonresonant frequencies, and if the molecule is already excited, even radiation at the correct frequency will be rejected (scattered) by the molecule (thus a heated CO2 molecule will not absorb another photon) and the energy transfer from a photon to increase a temperature requires that the wavelength to be shorter than the wavelength frequency absorbing it. In simple thermodynamics it is the same concept as hot to cold only on a micro scale. 

CO2 does not have a magnetic dipole in a relaxed state, which means it must become IR active by way of collision/conduction or heated in some other manner.  Atmospheric molecules are either Raman active or IR active as a general rule of thumb, not both at the same time.

#4 Absorption is affected by temperature. If you want a surface to be a good absorber, cool it off. If you could cool to Absolute Zero, the surface would be a perfect ‚Äúblack body‚Äù, able to absorb all photons. If you heated a surface to a very high temperature it would be a very poor absorber. At room temperatures, infrared wavelengths are typically not absorbed.   

#5 You often hear ‚ÄúIf a system has more energy coming in than going out, its temperature MUST increase‚Äù. They apply that nonsense to Earth‚Äôs surface (the ‚Äúsystem‚Äù) by misinterpreting entropy. Adding more CO2 to the atmosphere means more infrared energy coming back to Earth. So, in their version of science, they believe that means surface temperatures must raise.  

Again this energy is already in the system, not new energy being put in the system. Photons being reflected are being emitted from a radiation source on the surface and some of those photons are returning by way of re-radiating or reflecting at the speed of light back to the surface from a line spectrum, Delta E =hf ( Change in energy equals Plank‚Äôs Constant 6.626x10^34 J s and the frequency of emitting and absorbing EM radiation.) 

Of course infrared impacting the surface does NOT imply absorption. (See #1.) You CAN add energy to a system without increasing temperatures. 

Bring a bowl of ice cream into your den. The ice cream is emitting infrared. You have ‚Äúadded energy‚Äù to the system (den), but do you expect the room temperature to increase? Or, add a liter of water at 40 degrees to a large bowl already containing water at 45 degrees. You have added energy to the large bowl (system), but the average temperature DROPS. Thermodynamic ‚Äúheat‚Äù has two components: 1) energy transfer, and 2) from ‚Äúhot‚Äù to ‚Äúcold‚Äù (ŒîT). Without both components, there is no ‚Äúheat‚Äù just a transfer of energy. No heat=no raise in temperature.  

So that is what happens to the energy. Anyone claiming otherwise is misrepresenting the physics.  

ALL climate science (influenced by politics) is doing the same thing from the same starting point that everyone else supporting CO2 Climate Change does: they believe that the flux from the atmosphere must be warming the surface because they believe that the Sun cannot possibly be the sole source of heat ALONE .

They remotely measure a temperature, and then believe that this temperature ADDS with other temperatures to give a final higher temperature. What‚Äôs the temperature of a radiative 200 W/m^2 emission??? Its 243K or -30 C remotely measuring a temperature does not mean that temperature adds or is adding to your warmer temperature. 

By mismanaging the actual Sun‚Äôs potential power they can add the Greenhouse Theory as a supplement to justify the surface temperature already provided by the Sun and by misinterpreting entropy (by assuming energy is always heat) they think they have proven it. 

They have proven no such thing.

text:
¬†@Erik Davis¬† I explained all of this to you before.

Gravity/adiabatic/compression the closer to the center of mass you get the warmer the air becomes, the farther away the cooler. In physics it‚Äôs called the Maxwell gravito-thermal theory it has also been coined the Maxwell gravito-thermal greenhouse effect theory. Richard Feynman mentioned the mechanics of the process a few times. 
‚Ä¶
6 basic processes determine a change in troposphere air temperature and of those processes only one does it without the addition of energy. Not one of these processes is the ghge or even supports the theory of the ghge. 


>5 are a diabatic process, "A thermodynamic change of state of a system in which the system exchanges energy with its surroundings by virtue of a temperature difference between them".


 1. Conduction: 
>Solar irradiance heats the Earth's surface and by contact the lower troposphere.
 
2. Convection:
 >That hot air rises. 


3. Advection:
 >Horizontal movement of air. 


4. Radiation:
 >Exchanging thermal energy to space. Radiation is thermal energy transferred away from Earth by the emissions of electromagnetic waves to space and the only means of emissions of energy off the planet. 


>80% of the EM radiation escapes to space through the open atmospheric window between 8-13 micron. 


*>The 20% that is intercepted by greenhouse gases has created an entire branch of incorrect climate science.* 


5. Latent Heat: 
>The water phase which transfers en masse thermal energy from the surface to the atmosphere and powers our climate via the Hadley cells. 


6. Adiabatic Process: "A process in which there is no exchange of heat or mass with the environment. In an adiabatic process, a change in internal energy is solely a consequence of work. For an ideal gas and most atmospheric conditions, compression results in warming, whereas expansion results in cooling."


 >Without work from the outside only this process remains, air expands as it rises and compresses as that air descends. Thus the troposphere functions as a Carnot cycle (as atmospheric science teaches): 


>Reversible isothermal expansion 
>Reversible adiabatic expansion 
>Reversible isothermal compression 
>Reversible adiabatic compression 


Now the lapse rate, "The decrease of an atmospheric variable with height, the variable being temperature, unless otherwise specified." Is reversible, meaning: "Thus the same parcel of air at the surface is warmer than it is as it rises in the atmosphere, just as the potential energy of that parcel of air declines as it moves back towards the earth's surface. The lapse rate cools the hotter air as it rises and warms it as it lowers." 


Kinetic energy/potential energy. 
All energy loss from a heated material is cooling.


The three cooling mechanisms are:
1. Conduction (which in the case of conduction to air in a gravity field leads to convection, the adiabatic process which is flux asymmetric, it acts like a one-way gate).


2. Evaporation ‚Äì all evaporation is cooling. (Remember that Latent Heat is a hidden store of energy, it has no kinetic signature).


3. Thermal Radiation (the diabatic process which is a gradient flux cascade of half out and half back).


And for good measure there is also the issue of thermal inertia; the heat capacity of the body being warmed. The thermal capacity (specific heat) of water is much larger than that of air. Water takes longer to warm and stores more energy.


‚ÄúIt is impossible to radiate potential energy, so when held at elevation in a convection cell the former kinetic energy of the rising air mass is now locked into the air parcel by virtue of its position. This stored energy can only be released when the air descends and it losses potential energy but regains kinetic energy.‚Äù -Philip M. Geoscientist


"The ‚Äúplanet‚Äù does not ‚Äúwarm or cool‚Äù when there is an imbalance given by I = (S/4)(1-a) ‚Äì oeT^4. The ‚Äúplanet‚Äù warms and cools at every moment with the real-time in-situ heat flow." -Joseph Postma, physicist.

Now when you reference something what are your credentials again? Oh yes that's right, you never give any. 

You just spin because you are the spin doctor.

All I know is that heat cannot be produced from an object of lesser thermal temperature going to a higher thermal temperature. i.e. a lower frequency cannot add to a higher frequency and make it higher still.
Therefore if the sun produces an average temperature of say 15C at the surface, no amount of back radiation or side radiation or so called trapping radiation is going to produce a greater temperature than 15C...period. In other words a lower temperature, or thermal temperature, or frequency has nothing to add to a higher temperature or frequency. As in my analogy of the boiling water @40C...you can‚Äôt add 20C warm water and get more than the 40C that you started with! The sun produces whatever the sun produces during the day regardless of any so called trapping. 
If (and its a big if considering the last 5 years of colder winters around the world) the temperature is the hottest it has ever been, it has extremely little to do with CO2. Just ask the Chinese, they are powering on with cheap fossil fuels like there is no tomorrow and laughing at the West while we commit economic suicide.

He also continues to straw man me over and over and over. I can barely fit in enough in my replies to correct his straw men, much less go into detail on why he is wrong.

I'm not parroting anything. I am literally correcting his straw men. I don't call anything that deviates a straw man. I call his straw men "straw men." It isn't my fault he keeps lying about my position. If he would stop lying about my position I would stop calling him out for it.

You misunderstand thermodynamics. I have explained this multiple times already. Nobody, and I mean no person with any knowledge of the topic, says that a body of lower thermal energy is heating a body of higher thermal energy. I never said that. AGW doesn't say that. No expert has said that. Marshal simply lies and says we hold that position even after I state unequivocally that we do not say that.

GHGs increase atmospheric temperature, again, by slowing the rate of radiation loss. It is as simple as that. I have stated this over and over.

The sun doesn't create 15 C on earth. Solar forcing alone, with no GHGs in the atmosphere, would see an average of around -18 C. This is because, while the total energy from the sun would cause a higher temperature on earth during the day, much is lost at night. The average thus settles around -18 C. however, with GHGs in the atmosphere, the rate that the earth loses radiation to space slows. It thus loses less radiation per unit time. Thus the average temperature is higher than without GHGs. I quite literally can't make this more simple to understand. If you can't understand this, please study the topic because this is the most basic of basic aspects. I don't mean to insult you if you can't grasp it. It just means you are ignorant of the topic, and ignorance is not a bad thing. it simply means you can learn more than you know. Science is built on ignorance.

I'll try to explain with the analogy again. You have a pot of water and provide a set amount of energy to the pot. The energy after a set time increases the water to temperature "x." You then turn the flow of energy off and allow the water to cool. You then take the average temperature over the entire time frame. You repeat this over and over and over and find the average temperature we'll call "y." Now, the energy being emitted by the radiation source is higher than the "x" value, but the water is not absorbing radiation long enough to reach that value. This potential value we'll call "z." So our current variables are:
x1-temperature water gets to
y1-average temperature
z-total potential temperature (always greater than x)

Now, if you add a barrier that slows the rate of energy loss from the water such as a glass dome, the rate of energy loss will slow. Thus the average value for the temperature will be greater than Y1. This can allow the new X2 value to be higher than X1. However, X2 will still be lower than Z. No extra energy has been added, and no energy has gone from a colder body to a warmer one. No laws of thermodynamics have been broken, but the temperature of the water will increase.

You can literally test this by conducting the experiment. Simply give a set time to warm and cool and a set amount of energy (turning burner or other source of energy to the same temperature each time that is higher than the water gets, preferably keeping the water below boiling so as to not cause a decrease in mass, kinetic energy transfer, sound, and the like). For example provide a source of energy that could potentially increase the temperature to, say, 150 but only supply the energy source for an amount of time that keeps the water from reaching 150 degrees. Granted, you will need to conduct the experiment very carefully so as to not contaminate it and will need a very precise heating element.

The winters haven't been colder around the world. You are confusing local cold spikes for global temperature. That said, it is possible to have a record cold winter while the average global temperature goes up, especially since "polar vortex" behavior was a predicted effect of AGW, and that is what causes the massive cold spikes we see even though the global average increases.

Thus the energy can increase but that does not increase the temperature.

First, it assumes that the science doesn't take into account adiabatic and convective forces despite the fact that we do. Second, it assumes only feedback loops that help their conclusion and ignore the ones that don't (e.g., only assume clouds will have a cooling effect since they need the temperature to drop at a certain point despite clouds having both a cooling and warming effect that changes by type, height, and time of day). It even admits to the greenhouse effect being real, just not as potent as other work suggests. it also makes assumptions when it literally says "we assume" the extra heating in the atmosphere between the radiative and surface temperature is caused entirely by heat capacity. It doesn't prove it. It literally says to assume it. It also states that man's influence is small compared to nature so it should just be ignored and not factored in. In other words, it starts under the assumption man's influence shouldn't be factored in and then assumes values required for that specific conclusion, and then states that the conclusion is that man's influence shouldn't be taken into account. In doing so, however, it even admits that GHGs do function as we believe and that man is causing a change, just not large enough for them to merit factoring it in despite the fact that we already know that man's influence is small compared to nature. That is why the change has been relatively small, although enough to cause negative impacts for mankind.

text: ¬†@Gary Viehe¬† You are spreading historical nonsense. The ancients knew that the earth was round for two simple reasons. First, when ships sailed away from land, they disappeared below the horizon. Secondly, they observed that the earth cast a circular shadow on the moon during a lunar eclipse. Furthermore, Eratosthenes, who lived in Greece in the third century BC estimated the circumference of the Earth within 2% of the actual number. He used shadows and angles to come up with his result. He would have never made such a measurement if he thought the earth was flat. Columbus knew of these measurements, but because of a transcription error, Columbus greatly underestimated the length of his journey.

Thermodynamic heat (technically appropriate description in thermodynamics) must meet a requirement, Delta T, an energy transfer from hot to cold and is considered a transient phenomenon, heat is never contained in a system. Thus, CO2 does not trap heat, a physics impossibility and a deliberate misdirection by climate consensus science. 

Fundamental physics radiative heat transfer: Q=s*(Th^4-Tc^4)

Q
"Heat may be defined as energy in transit from a high temperature object to a lower temperature object. An object does not possess "heat"; the appropriate term for the microscopic energy in an object is internal energy. The internal energy may be increased by transferring energy to the object from a higher temperature (hotter) object - this is properly called heating." -HyperPhysics

I will try to explain very simply here one of the phenomena of Greenhouse gases, but I will probably fail:
So Greenhouse gases absorb some percent of energy (specific wavelengths of the electromagnetic spectrum) and even reflect some. But most actually go through and then absorbed and reradiated by the ground itself, this reradiated energy (thermal radiation) again absorbed by the greenhouse gases or reflected back to the earth, that is what many call the "trapping of heat". 
The energy emitted by the Sun pretty much constant, what changes are the amount of energy earth losses, if there are more greenhouse gases, then there is less percent of the total energy (radiation) of the Sun is being radiated out into space from earth. Making the earth lose energy at less of a rate than before, which will cause global warming.

‚ÄúYou are free to name them.‚Äù

‚ÄúPff. So it is called "greenhouse effect", cause greenhouses glasses keep some of the energy in which was absorbed by the contents of the greenhouse (like the ground itself).‚Äù

The atmosphere is not a blackbody; it does not behave like ‚Äúthe ground‚Äù. A gas absorbs spectral lines it does not emit radiation as a source. CO2 is not a heat source and neither is the atmosphere thus heat transfer must be allocated accordingly from the source and that energy conversion from the Sun to the surface is not reversible. In case it still wasn‚Äôt clear, that means the Sun is the source of energy. 

As long as our surface is free to convect it is free to cool so no, absolutely NOT like a greenhouse. A greenhouse functions by preventing or largely restricting convection. CO2 is pumped full in greenhouses and it does not change the temperature one bit.

‚Äúeven on youtube, there are countless videos showing it somewhat on very small scales.‚Äù

It‚Äôs called the Ideal Gas Law, Pv=nRT, increased pressure of a gas makes compression which increases kinetic energy which increases temperature it is the same process that creates the adiabatic lapse rate in our atmosphere. Any gas with a higher molar mass than an average parcel of air (like CO2) will compress more and increase temperature, really just high school physics.

"Thermodynamic heat can be produced but never contained in a system." I meant exactly what I said.

Q
‚ÄúHeat is defined as the form of energy that is transferred across a boundary by virtue of a temperature difference or temperature gradient. Implied in this definition is the very important fact that a body never contains heat, but that heat is identified as heat only as it crosses the boundary. Thus, heat is a transient phenomenon‚Ä¶‚Äù -Thermodynamics, G. J. V. Wylen, John Wiley & Sons, 1960

‚ÄúHeat is defined as any spontaneous flow of energy from one object to another caused by a difference in temperature between the objects‚Ä¶ The mechanism may be different in each case, but in each of these processes the energy transferred is called ‚Äúheat .‚Äù -Chapter 1 ‚Äì Energy in Thermal Physics Daniel V. Schroeder: An Introduction to Thermal Physics

‚Äú‚Ä¶Thus ‚Äòheat‚Äô may be termed as the energy interaction at the system boundary which occurs due to temperature difference only. Heat is observable in transit at the interface i.e. boundary, it cannot be contained in a system‚Äù ‚ÄìApplied Thermodynamics by Onkar Singh

Our Troposphere functions as a Carnot cycle (Google it) as such it is not in thermal equilibrium and it will never be in thermal equilibrium  and claiming COE (conservation of energy) dictates the atmosphere must be in thermal equilibrium is an error in understanding the LOT (Laws of Thermodynamics), ‚Äòheat in does not equal heat out‚Äô. 

Energy in equals energy out and if the appropriate allocations for that energy was provided in the consensus science energy budgets that balance of energy would be evident in a 24 hour period. 

Energy in reaching the SURFACE: 910-980 W/m^2 (Greater solar density flux dictates a more concentrated volume of energy in but only on half the planet and half the time of the outgoing flux). Greater density flux means the energy coming in is hotter than the energy going out.

 Energy out: 227.5 W/m^2 ‚Äì 245 W/m^2 (Over the entire planet in 24 hours thus less density flux over an extended period of time.) 

>Anything emitting above 0 Kelvin emits energy that does not mean it‚Äôs increasing the temperature. Energy does not automatically mean a temperature change. Thermodynamic ‚Äúheat‚Äù has two components: 1) energy transfer, and 2) from ‚Äúhot‚Äù to ‚Äúcold‚Äù, Delta T.

Without both components, there is no ‚Äúheat‚Äù just a transfer of energy. No heat=no raise in temperature thus the equation, (Th^4 ‚Äì Tc^4) from hot to cold.

The greenhouse effect does not mean an increase in surface temperature for a radiative source (the surface) cannot increase its own temperature without work especially from spectral lines for the atmosphere is not a radiative source, ergo, a black body. 

I think that‚Äôs enough for now.

text:
¬†@Slythia¬† Thermal energy is not heat (technically), it can produce heat. A temperature increase needs a requirement, Delta T from hot to cold. Energy can move both ways in a system, heat  requires specific conditions.  At least read the definitions provided so I don't have to repeat myself.

"Second Law of Thermodynamics It is not possible for heat to flow from a colder body to a warmer body without any work having been done to accomplish this flow. Energy will not flow spontaneously from a low temperature object to a higher temperature object. This precludes a perfect refrigerator. The statements about refrigerators apply to air conditioners and heat pumps, which embody the same principles. 

It is important to note that when it is stated that energy will not spontaneously flow from a cold object to a hot object, that statement is referring to net transfer of energy. Energy can transfer from the cold object to the hot object either by transfer of energetic particles or electromagnetic radiation, but the net transfer will be from the hot object to the cold object in any spontaneous process . **Work is required to transfer net energy to the hot object.**" -HyperPhysics 

Water phase changes are a product of a temperature change, the adiabatic process is the only atmospheric process that does not require a change in temperature of the system, it is dependent completely on work.  6 basic processes determine a change in troposphere air temperature and of those processes only one does it without the addition of energy. Not one of these processes is the ghge or even supports the theory of the ghge. 

Thermal energy exchange does not always equal a temperature increase. Solar energy is not a given for a temperature increase. The requirement is still for the receiving surface to be cooler than the energy/wavelength/frequency coming in.

In other words, energy absorbing into a mass does not equate a change in temperature unless the specific requirements are met.

¬†@Slythia¬† You brought up this, "Actual scientists present the whole truth and not the half (if that) of the evidence that supports their claim. This guy is is using lies of omission."

I challenged,
"Are you educated in climate science? If so I'll be happy to challenge you on the "claims" and "evidence"  consensus climate science follows."

I mentioned this to Hook,
"When I can't get an honest answer to the question what is the difference between heat and energy, and all replies from climate science are cookie cutter bullet points, then yes I do ask the questions. Anyone can study science and  last I checked 2+2=4 no matter who solves it."

You responded,
"Scientifically heat is a transfer of energy and temperature is a measurement of average thermal energy in a system." followed by snide remarks.

I clarified.
"Temperature (simplest definition) is a measure of kinetic energy and cannot produce thermodynamic heat unless it can increase temperature. Just because something has a temperature, does not mean it can produce heat."

In thermodynamics, heat, temperature and energy have specific definitions and functions. In other words, energy absorbing into a mass does not equate a change in temperature unless the specific requirements are met.

Heat is a transfer of energy yes if the proper requirements are met. Thermal energy has a temperature, but more technically kinetic energy is how we measure temperature. 

Do you deny this for some reason?

Ice cubes have a temperature.
An ice cube can produce heat on something colder than itself. 
An ice cube cannot produce heat on something warmer than itself.
Something warmer than the ice cube can transfer heat to the ice cube.
An ice cube in a freezer under thermal equilibrium can transfer energy freely in the freezer and not change the temperature.

This is why the radiative heat transfer equation is (Th^4-Tc^4) hot to cold. Climate science (not all but a quite a few) mix up distinctions between heat and energy to push an agenda of warming. Energy moving through a system is not always counted as thermodynamic heat that is increasing the temperature.

"So you think an ice cube sitting for example on a table at room temperature won't produce some heat? (and I am not speaking of net heat) "

NO. It will emit **energy**.
The net difference is always the heat. 
No difference not heat.
If it is two systems are constantly changing temperature for some reason, the net difference is always the heat.

My example:
Ice cubes have a temperature.


An ice cube can produce heat on something colder than itself. 


An ice cube cannot produce heat on something warmer than itself.


Something warmer than the ice cube can transfer heat to the ice cube.


An ice cube in a freezer under thermal equilibrium can transfer energy freely in the freezer and not change the temperature.

Another example,
 "Bring a bowl of ice cream into your den. The ice cream is emitting infrared. You have ‚Äúadded energy‚Äù to the system (den), but do you expect the room temperature to increase? Or, add a liter of water at 40 degrees to a large bowl already containing water at 45 degrees. You have added energy to the large bowl (system), but the average temperature DROPS. Thermodynamic ‚Äúheat‚Äù has two components: 1) energy transfer, and 2) from ‚Äúhot‚Äù to ‚Äúcold‚Äù ( Delta T)."

¬†@CD Marshall¬† does the ground or any surface in direct sunlight feel warmer than in the shade? Absolutely. This means at least some of the energy transmitted from the sun is being turned into thermal energy and is not just scattered off of the planet.

Secondly, I already addressed your statement about the Troposphere as a Carnot Cycle but since you didn‚Äôt listen here‚Äôs a quote:

‚ÄúThe atmosphere crucially does not act as a Carnot cycle. For instance, the average surface heating is about 100 Watts per meter square. With an average surface temperature of 288K and an emission temperature of 255K, the work done by a Carnot cycle would be about 11 Watts per meter square. By contrast, typical estimates of the kinetic energy dissipation in the atmosphere are between 2 and 5 Watts per meter square. The difference between the Carnot upper limit and the generation of kinetic energy can be attributed to the hydrological cycle, and in particular to two key aspect of the Earth atmosphere: (1) it rains, and (2) the atmosphere is mostly dry.‚Äù Found at https://wp.nyu.edu/opauluis/home/research-atmospheric-heat-engine/

I‚Äôm done responding to you at this point. You too are either only stating facts that help your side instead of reviewing everything or you are refusing to check if you might be wrong. I hope you will learn how to present all of the facts like a scientist rather than be a propagandist.

Air parcels in the troposphere are also treated as individual systems doesn't mean they are literally individual systems but they can "function" at times "like" a individual system. "As" refers to the obvious, the adiabatic process,
>Reversible isothermal expansion
>Reversible adiabatic expansion 
>Reversible isothermal compression 
>Reversible adiabatic compression

Which is LIKE a Carnot cycle.

Plus you have the five main diabatic processes: Conduction, convection, advection, radiation and latent heat.

text:
The best lies have elements of truth. THE GREENHOUSE EFFECT IS ADIABATIC HEATING IN REALITY (the greenhouse effect does not exist). The Sun does the work of inflating the atmosphere against the force of gravity in the same way you do physical work climbing up to the top of a cliff. On top of a cliff, you have potential energy. If you do a base jump, your potential energy is converted to kinetic energy as you fall (i.e. when you speed up). Atmospheric pressure (caused by gravity together with the mass of the atmosphere) causes thermal (=kinetic) energy in the case of gases. Any volume V of any gas at pressure P has a steady and constant thermal energy P(N/m2) x V (m3) = N x m = J(Joules) = nRT. Thus for a given mole amount of gas ( n), PV/T = nR (a constant) or P1V1/T1=P2V2/T2.
T1 =214 K +/- (Temperature from solar radiation @Tropopause)
T2 = P2V2/P1V1 x T1 (above gas law solved for T2)
     = 101.3x1/(22.8 x 3.3) x 214
     = 288 K (Earth Surface, subject to minor variations +/-1 K associated with albedo and imperfect adiabatic system)

text: 27:49 It's only half of the story. The curves described are really thermo-electric curves and are misleading, and the GHGs are really only the thermoelectric gases and are misleading. However, from this curve came Planck's quantum solutions and from that came quantum explanations to spectra lines and later came quantum-based lasers. If we use the other complementary instrument to the IR spectrometer, the Raman laser-based spectrometer, we can measure the IR spectra lines of Oxygen and Nitrogen and all the other gases and their respective temperatures. Greenhouse theory is a systematic error played out over 161 years since Tyndall and his use of the thermopile. ¬†@Ray V.¬† I provided no gish gallop, and Gary didn't either. He brought up one or two topics he didn't need to if he were wanting to only address a single aspect of what you said, but the vast majority involved answering your statements or questions.

We don't simply look at small sections of time to say the climate is warming or cooling. We look at the long-term trend. The current trend indicates warming.

"Present" for that data is normally 1950, but the source you provided didn't give at actual time for what "present" means. The graph is thus not very useful. That said, it does show that global temperatures were, based on historic trend, going to begin decreasing but instead became steady and began increasing as our CO2 emissions began to rise at the end of the graph. We actually know this is what happened because the natural forcings that cause increases in atmospheric temperature have been indicating a cooling, not warming climate. We are, however, adding enough CO2 to cause it to instead continue to warm. Little more can be garnered from it, sadly. The temperature can also be higher with lower CO2 concentrations if other natural forcings are strong enough. We have, indeed, had times in the past where natural forcings could have allowed for a warmer atmosphere with a lower CO2 ppm, but that doesn't have anything to do with CO2's current influence.

The GISP you are using doesn't say what you think it does. That data, for a fact, only goes through 1855. The data begins 95 years before present, and "present" for GISP2 core data is 1950. It has been warmer than 1855 in the past, but 1855 was before our emissions began to increase rapidly.

Fundamental physics radiative heat transfer: Q=s*(Th^4-Tc^4)

Q

"Heat may be defined as energy in transit from a high temperature object to a lower temperature object. An object does not possess "heat"; the appropriate term for the microscopic energy in an object is internal energy. The internal energy may be increased by transferring energy to the object from a higher temperature (hotter) object - this is properly called heating." -HyperPhysics

Energy moving through the atmospheric system is not heat. For that energy to become heat it must first meet the appropriate thermodynamic requirements, (Th^4-Tc^4). 

Energy transfer from a15 micron photon is not enough energy to melt an ice cube  so how does CO2 reach a higher vibrational/rotational state? CO2 is unaffected by nonresonant frequencies, and if CO2 is already excited, even radiation at the correct frequency will be rejected (scattered) by CO2 (thus a heated CO2 molecule will not absorb another photon) and the energy transfer from a photon to increase a temperature requires that the wavelength to be shorter than the wavelength frequency absorbing it. However, it can absorb KE in this process from collisional/bumping molecules even several times before emitting its absorbed photonic energy {which would increase the emitted energy}.

In other words it requires more kinetic energy than what CO2 can absorb by a 15 micron photon. So where does that energy come from?

"The internal energy may be increased by transferring energy to the object from a higher temperature (hotter) object " that would be heated molecules by conduction/convection/advection or anything that is absorbing Raman scattering or a higher spectrum of infrared radiation. Molecules with a higher heat capacity like N2 and O2 would carry more internal energy than CO2 (even methane has a slightly higher HC than CO2 as does H20).

*Note CO2 in its symmetric mode is Raman active NOT IR active.*

So what happens when homonuclear diatomic molecules collide/bump with a molecule with a dipole moment with less kinetic energy? It transfers that energy to the other molecule. Since CO2 once vibrating emits IR it essentially cools homonuclear diatomic molecules faster (that can‚Äôt shed IR off via emissions) after CO2 absorbs some of the transferred energy from those molecules. None magnetic dipole molecules of course radiate EM once heated, and can cool off but that takes longer without being able to shed off that IR. Magnetic dipole molecules cool the atmosphere off faster by absorbing some of the energy from higher energy emitting molecules and ejecting that energy at the speed of light which non IR molecules cannot do.

So no, CO2 is not warming the atmosphere it helps to cool it off faster by stealing energy from hotter molecules and re-radiating that energy in all directions. That does not mean any energy directed at the ground will be re-absorbed, it may very well just reflect back out to space, or a cloud or scatter on another molecule. 

>A single photon can be absorbed by CO2 and emit in around 70 microseconds.

text:
The Climate Science:

6 basic processes determine a change in troposphere air temperature and of those processes only one does it without the addition of energy. Not one of these processes is the ghge or even supports the theory of the ghge. 

>5 are a diabatic process, "A thermodynamic change of state of a system in which the system exchanges energy with its surroundings by virtue of a temperature difference between them".

 1. Conduction: 
>Solar irradiance heats the Earth's surface and by contact the lower troposphere. 

2. Convection:
 >That hot air rises. 

3. Advection:
 >Horizontal movement of air. 

4. Latent Heat: 

>The water phase which transfers en masse thermal energy from the surface to the atmosphere and powers our climate via the Hadley cells. 

5. Radiation:
 >Exchanging thermal energy to space. Radiation is thermal energy transferred away from Earth by the emissions of electromagnetic waves to space and the only means of emissions of energy off the planet. 

>80% of the EM radiation escapes to space through the open atmospheric window between 8-13 micron. 

>The 20% that is intercepted by greenhouse gases has created an entire branch of incorrect climate science. 

6. Adiabatic Process: "A process in which there is no exchange of heat or mass with the environment. In an adiabatic process, a change in internal energy is solely a consequence of work. For an ideal gas and most atmospheric conditions, compression results in warming, whereas expansion results in cooling."

 >Without work from the outside only this process remains, air expands as it rises and compresses as that air descends. Thus the troposphere functions as a Carnot cycle (as atmospheric science teaches): 
>Reversible isothermal expansion 
>Reversible adiabatic expansion 
>Reversible isothermal compression 
>Reversible adiabatic compression 

Now the lapse rate, "The decrease of an atmospheric variable with height, the variable being temperature, unless otherwise specified." Is reversible, meaning: "Thus the same parcel of air at the surface is warmer than it is as it rises in the atmosphere, just as the potential energy of that parcel of air declines as it moves back towards the earth's surface. The lapse rate cools the hotter air as it rises and warms it as it lowers." 

Kinetic energy/potential energy.

Our emissions are having such an effect that they, based on data we have, are reversing the natural course of climate, and the natural cooling forces are actually helping to limit CO2's influence. Third, CO2 does show diminishing returns. We already know that. However, we have not hit a value that would cause significant reductions in amplification with increased CO2 due to oversaturation yet.
